Q: Four weeks after starting hydrochlorothiazide, a 49-year-old man with hypertension comes to the physician because of muscle cramps and weakness. His home medications also include amlodipine. His blood pressure today is 176/87 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The precordial leads of a 12-lead ECG are shown. The addition of which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?
(A) Torsemide (B) Nifedipine (C) Eplerenone (D) Hydralazine
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has started hydrochlorothiazide. He now presents with muscle cramps and weakness and an ECG that supports the diagnosis of hypokalemia. The addition of (A) Torsemide is a loop diuretic and would likely aggravate the hypokalemia, (B) Nifedipine is a calcium antagonist and would not alleviate the hypocalcemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potassium-sparing diuretic and would likely decrease the chance of hypokalemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potent vasodilator and would not decrease the risk of hypokalemia. The answer is (C).

Q: A 57-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe pain around her right eye, blurred vision in the same eye, and a headache for the past 4 hours. She is nauseous but has not vomited. She can see colored bright circles when she looks at a light source. She is currently being treated for a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. She appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows visual acuity of 20/20 in the left eye and counting fingers at 5 feet in the right eye. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. Intravenous analgesia and antiemetics are administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Perform ultrasound biomicroscopy (B) Perform gonioscopy (C) Perform fundoscopy (D) Administer topical steroids
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has severe pain, blurred vision, and a headache. She is also nauseous but has not vomited. She can see bright colored circles when she looks at a light source. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. The tentative (most likely) diagnosis, given the patient's symptoms, is acute primary angle-closure glaucoma. Analgesics have been administered. The next step is to confirm the tentative diagnosis using the gold standard test. (A) ultrasound biomicroscopy could be used but are not widely available, (B) Gonioscopy is the gold-standard test to confirm the diagnosis of acute primary angle-closure glaucoma, (C) fundoscopy is not as reliable as gonioscopy, (D) topical steroids is not relevant, the possible medical therapy would be timolol, apraclonidine or pilocarpine. The most appropriate next step in management is to administer intravenous analgesia and antiemetics. The answer is (B).

Q: A 55-year-old man with a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia presents for follow-up 4 days into the treatment of a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. His symptoms have resolved, and he reports no problems with urination, with the exception of a weak urine stream and hesitancy, which he has had for the past 2 years. At the time of this visit, the patient is afebrile; the blood pressure is 130/88 mm Hg and the heart rate is 80/min. There is no flank tenderness. A urinalysis reveals no leukocytes and is negative for esterase. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality:
Prior treatment
BUN 12 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL
Today’s visit
BUN 13 mg/dL
Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL
(A) Reassure the patient, stop trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and repeat the measurement in 1–2 weeks (B) Schedule an intravenous pyelography for urinary obstruction (C) Schedule a cystoscopy for urethral obstruction (D) Admit the patient for further management of acute interstitial nephritis
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia. These are both risk factors for urinary tract infections. The patient is being treated with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for a urinary tract infection. The symptoms have resolved, but the patient has a weak urine stream and hesitancy. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality: BUN 12 mg/dL, Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL (prior treatment) vs BUN 13 mg/dL, Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL (today’s visit). The BUN and creatinine levels have increased from the prior visit. This could be due to acute interstitial nephritis. A known but rare side effect of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Interstitial nephritis should be suspected if there is an elevated creatinine and a urinalysis that shows white cells, white cell casts, and, in some cases, eosinophiluria. Since none of the urinalysis results is present and the patient has no typical symptoms such as fever, rash, or acute interstitial nephritis is an unlikely diagnosis. The answer is (A).

Q: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles for the past 16 months. She began having symptoms of insomnia and depression 10 months ago. More recently, she has been having difficulties rising from a chair. She has a 2-year history of hypertension. Current medications include citalopram and hydrochlorothiazide. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb). BMI is 36 kg/m2. Her pulse is 92/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 134/76 mm Hg. She appears tired and has a full, plethoric face and central obesity. Examination of the skin shows violaceous linear striations on her lower abdomen. Two midnight serum cortisol studies show measurements of 288 μg/L and 253 μg/L (N < 90); a 24-hour urinary cortisol measurement was 395 μg (N < 300). Upon follow-up laboratory examination, the patient's serum ACTH levels were also elevated at 136 pg/mL (N = 7–50). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
(A) MRI of the head with contrast (B) Measure ACTH levels in inferior petrosal sinuses (C) High-dose dexamethasone suppression test (D) CT scan of the abdomen with contrast
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has Cushing's syndrome, which is characterized by weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles. She also has symptoms of insomnia and depression, which could be caused by Cushing's syndrome. Additionally, she has difficulties rising from a chair, which could be caused by muscle weakness. The two elevated serum cortisol measurements and the elevated ACTH levels confirm the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome. A high dose dexamethasone suppression test will help determine if the cause of Cushing's syndrome is Cushing's disease (CS caused by pituitary hypersecretion of ACTH) or ectopic ACTH syndrome (CS caused by nonpituitary ACTH-secreting tumors). Since the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome is established, the most appropriate next step is to distinguish between Cushing's disease and ectopic ACTH syndrome using the high-dose dexamethasone suppression test. The answer is (C).

Q: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a nonpruritic rash. He has been feeling more tired than usual and occasionally experiences pain in his wrists and ankles. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows multiple, erythematous, purpuric papules on his trunk and extremities that do not blanch when pressed. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The patient's hemoglobin is 14 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9,500/mm3, and platelet count is 228,000/mm3. Urinalysis and liver function tests are within normal limits. The test for rheumatoid factor is positive. Serum ANA is negative. Serum complement levels are decreased. Serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation shows increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. Testing for cryoglobulins shows no precipitate after 24 hours. Chest x-ray and ECG show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Rapid plasma reagin test (B) Hepatitis C serology (C) pANCA assay (D) Bence Jones protein test
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a rash, fatigue, and pain in his wrists and ankles. He has normal hemoglobin (normal range 13.8-17.2 g/dL), normal leukocyte count (normal range 4500-11000 wbc/microliter), and normal platelet count (normal range 150-450 platelets/microliter). His serum complement levels are decreased. His serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation show increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. The cryoglobulin precipitation test is normal, ruling out cryoglobulinemia. Serum ANA is negative, so Lupus is less likely. Physical examination and symptoms are consistent with possible non-cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. The most likely associated diagnosis is Hepatitis C. The answer is (B).

Q: A 67-year-old male comes into the ED complaining of dyspnea and a heavy feeling in his chest. He reports that over the past month he has become more easily “winded" to the point that he now sleeps in his living room because he can’t make it up the stairs. A review of systems is notable for headaches and fatigue. On physical exam you note decreased breath sounds and a dullness to percussion on the right. A chest radiograph is obtained, which shows a right-sided pleural effusion. Thoracocentesis is performed and the fluid is analyzed, with results shown below:

Volume: 30 cc of fluid
Pleural fluid protein: 5.8 g/dL
Serum protein ratio: 7.0 g/dL
Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH): 258 U/L

Which of the following conditions may have led to the findings in this patient’s pleural cavity?
(A) Congestive heart failure (B) Liver cirrhosis (C) Lymphoma (D) Nephrotic syndrome
A: Let's think step by step.
question:
Q: A 67-year-old male comes into the ED complaining of dyspnea and a heavy feeling in his chest. He reports that over the past month he has become more easily “winded" to the point that he now sleeps in his living room because he can’t make it up the stairs. A review of systems is notable for headaches and fatigue. On physical exam you note decreased breath sounds and a dullness to percussion on the right. A chest radiograph is obtained, which shows a right-sided pleural effusion. Thoracocentesis is performed and the fluid is analyzed, with results shown below:

Volume: 30 cc of fluid
Pleural fluid protein: 5.8 g/dL
Serum protein ratio: 7.0 g/dL
Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH): 258 U/L

Which of the following conditions may have led to the findings in this patient’s pleural cavity?
options: (A) Congestive heart failure (B) Liver cirrhosis (C) Lymphoma (D) Nephrotic syndrome
outputs:
The patient has shortness of breath and a heavy feeling in his chest. He also reports headaches and fatigue. The physical examination shows decreased breath sounds and a dullness to percussion on the right. A chest radiograph shows a right-sided pleural effusion. Thoracocentesis is performed, and the fluid analysis shows a pleural fluid protein of 5.8 g/dL, a serum protein ratio of 7.0 g/dL, and an LDH of 258 U/L. These findings are consistent with a pleural effusion caused by congestive heart failure. The patient's shortness of breath and heavy feeling in his chest are consistent with congestive heart failure. The pleural effusion is likely caused by increased pressure in the pulmonary veins, which can lead to fluid accumulation in the pleural cavity. The answer is (A).

Q: A 68-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of sudden onset of severe left knee pain. She has a history of osteoarthritis and has been taking ibuprofen as needed. She appears uncomfortable and has a guarded, antalgic gait. The left knee is swollen and tender to palpation. The patient's blood pressure is 188/92 mm Hg, heart rate is 110/min, respirations are 20/min, and temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Order an urgent MRI of the left knee (B) Administer intravenous ketorolac (C) Perform an arthrocentesis (D) Order an urgent radiograph of the left knee
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of osteoarthritis and is taking ibuprofen as needed. She presents with sudden onset of severe left knee pain, swelling, and tenderness to palpation. The patient's blood pressure is elevated. The most likely diagnosis is a knee effusion secondary to osteoarthritis. The most appropriate next step in management would be to perform an arthrocentesis to drain the effusion and relieve the patient's pain. The answer is (C).

Q: A 50-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of painful urination and a 1-week history of hematuria. He has been feeling more tired than usual. He has a history of smoking and drinks 2–3 beers per day. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 140/88 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Urinalysis shows 10–20 RBC/hpf, 1+ protein, and 1+ blood. A urine cytology specimen is obtained. The patient's serum creatinine level is 1.2 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Initiate antibiotic therapy for acute prostatitis (B) Schedule a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis (C) Perform a cystoscopy (D) Administer intravenous fluids and observe for possible acute kidney injury
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of smoking and drinks 2–3 beers per day. He presents with painful urination and hematuria. The urinalysis shows 10–20 RBC/hpf, 1+ protein, and 1+ blood. The patient's serum creatinine level is 1.2 mg/dL. The most likely diagnosis is acute prostatitis. The patient's symptoms and urinalysis findings are consistent with acute prostatitis. The elevated serum creatinine level suggests that the patient may have acute kidney injury, which is a common complication of acute prostatitis. The answer is (A).

Q: A 57-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe pain around her right eye, blurred vision in the same eye, and a headache for the past 4 hours. She is nauseous but has not vomited. She can see colored bright circles when she looks at a light source. Examination shows visual acuity of 20/20 in the left eye and counting fingers at 5 feet in the right eye. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. (A) Perform ultrasound biomicroscopy (B) Perform gonioscopy (C) Perform fundoscopy (D) Administer topical steroids
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has severe pain, blurred vision, and a headache. She is also nauseous but has not vomited. The tentative (most likely) diagnosis, given the patient's symptoms, is acute primary angle-closure glaucoma. Analgesics have been administered. (A) ultrasound biomicroscopy could be used but are not widely available, (B) Gonioscopy is the gold-standard test to confirm the diagnosis of acute primary angle-closure glaucoma, (C) fundoscopy is not as reliable as gonioscopy, (D) topical steroids is not relevant, the possible medical therapy would be timolol, apraclonidine or pilocarpine. The most appropriate next step in management is to administer intravenous analgesia and antiemetics. The answer is (B).

Q: A 55-year-old man with a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia presents for follow-up 4 days into the treatment of a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia. These are both risk factors for urinary tract infections. Q: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles for the past 16 months. She began having symptoms of insomnia and depression 10 months ago. More recently, she has been having difficulties rising from a chair. She has a 2-year history of hypertension. Current medications include citalopram and hydrochlorothiazide. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb). BMI is 36 kg/m2. Her pulse is 92/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 134/76 mm Hg. She appears tired and has a full, plethoric face and central obesity. Examination of the skin shows violaceous linear striations on her lower abdomen. Two midnight serum cortisol studies show measurements of 288 μg/L and 253 μg/L (N < 90); a 24-hour urinary cortisol measurement was 395 μg (N < 300). Upon follow-up laboratory examination, the patient's serum ACTH levels were also elevated at 136 pg/mL (N = 7–50). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
(A) MRI of the head with contrast (B) Measure ACTH levels in inferior petrosal sinuses (C) High-dose dexamethasone suppression test (D) CT scan of the abdomen with contrast
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has Cushing's syndrome, which is characterized by weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles. She also has symptoms of insomnia and depression, which could be caused by Cushing's syndrome. Additionally, she has difficulties rising from a chair, which could be caused by muscle weakness. The two elevated serum cortisol measurements and the elevated ACTH levels confirm the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome. A high dose dexamethasone suppression test will help determine if the cause of Cushing's syndrome is Cushing's disease (CS caused by pituitary hypersecretion of ACTH) or ectopic ACTH syndrome (CS caused by nonpituitary ACTH-secreting tumors). Since the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome is established, the most appropriate next step is to distinguish between Cushing's disease and ectopic ACTH syndrome using the high-dose dexamethasone suppression test. The answer is (C).

Q: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a nonpruritic rash. He has been feeling more tired than usual and occasionally experiences pain in his wrists and ankles. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/75 mm Hg. A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a rash, fatigue, and pain in his wrists and ankles. His serum complement levels are decreased. His serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation show increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. The cryoglobulin precipitation test is normal, ruling out cryoglobulinemia. Serum ANA is negative, so Lupus is less likely. Physical examination and symptoms are consistent with possible non-cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. The most likely associated diagnosis is Hepatitis C. The answer is (B).

Q: A 22-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician in April for seasonal allergies. Her temperature is 99.2°F (37.3°C), blood pressure is 120/70 mmHg, pulse is 76/min, and respirations are 16/min. She has a prominent nasal crease. Her nasal turbinates are boggy and bluish-gray. She has copious thin and watery nasal mucus. The physician suggests replacing diphenhydramine with fexofenadine to improve her drowsiness. What characteristic of fexodenadine allows it to be less sedating than diphenhydramine?
(A) Alpha-adrenergic antagonism (B) Beta-adrenergic antagonism (C) Relative lipophobicity (D) Serotonergic antagonism
A: Let's think step by step.
question: Q: A 22-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician in April for seasonal allergies. She has suffered from seasonal allergies for the past 2 years and takes diphenhydramine as needed when her symptoms worsen. She has not yet seen a physician for her allergies. What characteristic of fexodenadine allows it to be less sedating than diphenhydramine?
options: (A) Alpha-adrenergic antagonism (B) Beta-adrenergic antagonism (C) Relative lipophobicity (D) Serotonergic antagonism
outputs:
Fexofenadine is an antihistamine that is less sedating than diphenhydramine. This is because fexofenadine has a relatively lipophobic property, which means it is less likely to cross the blood-brain barrier and cause sedation. Fexofenadine has a higher pKa, which makes it more ionized at physiologic pH, rendering it less capable of crossing the blood-brain barrier. Diphenhydramine, on the other hand, has a lower pKa, which makes it more lipid-soluble and capable of crossing the blood-brain barrier, leading to sedation. The answer is (C).

Q: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of fever and a rash. The rash began on his face and has spread to his trunk and limbs over the past 2 days. He has been afebrile until today, when his temperature rose to 102.2°F (39°C). He is currently taking no medications. He has no known allergies. He appears ill and has a moderate respiratory distress. His pulse oximetry on room air shows 92% saturation. His blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a diffuse, macular, confluent rash on his face, trunk, and extremities. There are no petechiae, purpura, or signs of meningism. A viral culture and PCR for herpes simplex virus are ordered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Administer acyclovir (B) Administer amoxicillin (C) Administer ceftriaxone and metronidazole (D) Administer azithromycin
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a fever and a rash that has spread from his face to his trunk and limbs over the past 2 days. He appears ill and has moderate respiratory distress. His blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. The patient's symptoms and physical examination are consistent with a viral exanthemata, such as roseola, fifth disease, and hand, foot, and mouth disease. The most appropriate next step in management would be to administer acyclovir, which is an antiviral medication that is effective against herpes simplex virus, the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms. The answer is (A).

Q: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles for the past 16 months. She began having symptoms of insomnia and depression 10 months ago. More recently, she has been having difficulties rising from a chair. She has a 2-year history of hypertension. Current medications include citalopram and hydrochlorothiazide. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb). BMI is 36 kg/m2. Her pulse is 92/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 134/76 mm Hg. She appears tired and has a full, plethoric face and central obesity. Examination of the skin shows violaceous linear striations on her lower abdomen. Two midnight serum cortisol studies show measurements of 288 μg/L and 253 μg/L (N < 90); a 24-hour urinary cortisol measurement was 395 μg (N < 300). Upon follow-up laboratory examination, the patient's serum ACTH levels were also elevated at 136 pg/mL (N = 7–50). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
(A) MRI of the head with contrast (B) Measure ACTH levels in inferior petrosal sinuses (C) High-dose dexamethasone suppression test (D) CT scan of the abdomen with contrast
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has Cushing's syndrome, which is characterized by weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles. She also has symptoms of insomnia and depression, which could be caused by Cushing's syndrome. Additionally, she has difficulties rising from a chair, which could be caused by muscle weakness. The two elevated serum cortisol measurements and the elevated ACTH levels confirm the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome. A high dose dexamethasone suppression test will help determine if the cause of Cushing's syndrome is Cushing's disease (CS caused by pituitary hypersecretion of ACTH) or ectopic ACTH syndrome (CS caused by nonpituitary ACTH-secreting tumors). Since the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome is established, the most appropriate next step is to distinguish between Cushing's disease and ectopic ACTH syndrome using the high-dose dexamethasone suppression test. The answer is (C).

Q: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a nonpruritic rash. He has been feeling more tired than usual and occasionally experiences pain in his wrists and ankles. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows multiple, erythematous, purpuric papules on his trunk and extremities that do not blanch when pressed. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The patient's hemoglobin is 14 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9,500/mm3, and platelet count is 228,000/mm3. Urinalysis and liver function tests are within normal limits. The test for rheumatoid factor is positive. Serum ANA is negative. Serum complement levels are decreased. Serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation shows increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. Testing for cryoglobulins shows no precipitate after 24 hours. Chest x-ray and ECG show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Rapid plasma reagin test (B) Hepatitis C serology (C) pANCA assay (D) Bence Jones protein test
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a rash, fatigue, and pain in his wrists and ankles. He has normal hemoglobin (normal range 13.8-17.2 g/dL), normal leukocyte count (normal range 4500-11000 wbc/microliter), and normal platelet count (normal range 150-450 platelets/microliter). His serum complement levels are decreased. His serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation show increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. The cryoglobulin precipitation test is normal, ruling out cryoglobulinemia. Serum ANA is negative, so Lupus is less likely. Physical examination and symptoms are consistent with possible non-cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. The most likely associated diagnosis is Hepatitis C. The answer is (B).

Q: A 56-year-old man recently diagnosed with cirrhosis secondary to alcohol use presents to the clinic for a follow up evaluation. He states that he has abstained from alcohol and attends a support group regularly. He has not taken any new medications or encountered any sick contacts. The patient's blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg, pulse is 65/min, and respirations are 15/min. His physical exam is grossly unremarkable. He has brought an gastroduodenoscopy report for review, which reveals that the patient has small esophageal varices with red spots. What is the next best step to prevent bleeding?
(A) Endoscopic sclerotherapy (B) Metoprolol (C) Nadolol (D) Repeat endoscopy
A: Let's think step by step.
question: Q: A 56-year-old man recently diagnosed with cirrhosis secondary to alcohol use presents to the clinic for a follow up evaluation. He states that he has abstained from alcohol and attends a support group regularly. He has not taken any new medications or encountered any sick contacts. The patient's blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg, pulse is 65/min, and respirations are 15/min. His physical exam is grossly unremarkable. options: (A) Endoscopic sclerotherapy (B) Metoprolol (C) Nadolol (D) Repeat endoscopy
outputs:
The patient has cirrhosis secondary to alcohol use. He has stopped drinking alcohol and attends a support group regularly. The patient's blood pressure and pulse are within normal limits. The patient's physical exam is grossly unremarkable. The gastroduodenoscopy report reveals that the patient has small esophageal varices with red spots. This is a sign of portal hypertension, which can lead to bleeding. The next best step to prevent bleeding is to perform endoscopic sclerotherapy. Endoscopic sclerotherapy is a minimally invasive procedure that involves injecting a sclerosing agent into the varices to obliterate them and prevent bleeding. The answer is (A).

Q: A 46-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and migraine headaches is evaluated for worsening headaches and blurred vision. She has no recent history of trauma or illness. Her blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a normal complete blood cell count, electrolyte panel, and liver function tests. A non-contrast head CT scan shows a 6-mm left parietal intracerebral hemorrhage. The patient is started on intravenous heparin and transferred to a neurological intensive care unit. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
(A) Cerebral amyloid angiopathy-related hemorrhage (B) Moyamoya disease (C) Hypertensive emergency (D) Vasculitis
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension and migraine headaches. She presents with worsening headaches and blurred vision. Her blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg. The non-contrast head CT scan shows a 6-mm left parietal intracerebral hemorrhage. The patient is started on intravenous heparin and transferred to a neurological intensive care unit. The patient's symptoms and the hemorrhage on the CT scan are consistent with a hypertensive emergency. This is a medical emergency that requires immediate attention. The answer is (C).

Q: A 57-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe pain around her right eye, blurred vision in the same eye, and a headache for the past 4 hours. Q: A 70-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife for incomprehensible speech. Upon first inspection you note the man is drooling and his eyes are tearing excessively. The patient seemed confused so the wife brought him in promptly, and states it has only been ten minutes since the patient was found down in the fields. Physical exam is deferred due to a confused and combative patient who is speaking clearly yet his sentences do not make any sense. The patients clothes are removed in the ED. question: Q: A 70-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife for incomprehensible speech. Upon first inspection you note the man is drooling and his eyes are tearing excessively. The patient's wife explains that the man was tilling the fields on the family beet farm when she found him collapsed on a pile of freshly picked beets. The patient seemed confused so the wife brought him in promptly, and states it has only been ten minutes since the patient was found down in the fields. Physical exam is deferred due to a confused and combative patient who is speaking clearly yet his sentences do not make any sense. The patients clothes are removed in the ED. Vital signs are currently being obtained. Which of the following is the best initial step in management?
options: (A) Neostigmine (B) Physostigmine (C) 2-pralidoxime (D) Intubation
outputs:
The patient is drooling and his eyes are tearing excessively. His wife found him collapsed on a pile of freshly picked beets. The patient seems confused and is speaking clearly but his sentences do not make any sense. The patient's clothes are removed in the ED. Vital signs are currently being obtained. The patient is combative. The most likely diagnosis is organophosphate poisoning. The patient is drooling and tearing excessively. The patient is confused and is speaking clearly but his sentences do not make any sense. The patient is combative. The patient is most likely experiencing seizures. The best initial step in management is to administer 2-pralidoxime. The answer is (C).

Q: A 45-year-old woman with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of worsening left knee pain. She has no history of previous knee injuries or surgeries. She currently takes metformin, lisinopril, and hydrochlorothiazide. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 85 kg (187 lb). BMI is 33 kg/m2. Her pulse is 86/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 138/82 mm Hg. Physical examination shows swelling and warmth of the left knee. There is no erythema or localized tenderness. The knee is not locked or effusive. The patient walks with a cane and appears to be in moderate distress. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Radiographs of the knee (B) Arthrocentesis (C) Intravenous antibiotics (D) Hip, knee, and ankle immobilizer
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. She has worsening left knee pain, swelling, and warmth. There is no erythema or localized tenderness. The knee is not locked or effusive. The patient walks with a cane and appears to be in moderate distress. The patient has no history of previous knee injuries or surgeries. The most likely diagnosis is osteoarthritis. The patient is in moderate distress. The patient should be immobilized with a hip, knee, and ankle immobilizer. The answer is (D).

Q: A 75-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of fever, chills, and worsening left flank pain. She has a history of hypertension and chronic kidney disease. A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension and chronic kidney disease. She has a 2-day history of fever, chills, and worsening left flank pain. She has costovertebral angle tenderness. There is no rebound tenderness. The patient appears uncomfortable. Urinalysis shows pyuria and hematuria. The most likely diagnosis is acute pyelonephritis. The patient should be given intravenous antibiotics. The answer is (C).

Q: A 75-year-old man presents to the physician for his annual blood pressure visit and blood work. He has no complaints other than occasional knee pain. The past medical history includes hypertension. He has had knee osteoarthritis for several years and takes occasional acetaminophen for pain control. His diet is full of vegetables. He exercises every day. He has no history of smoking. He had a brother who died at the age of 84 due to hematologic malignancy. The temperature is 36.8℃ (98.2℉), and the blood pressure is 125/85 mm Hg. The physical examination shows no abnormalities other than a reduced range of motion and crepitus in both knees. The laboratory test results are as follows:
Hemoglobin 15 g/dL
Leukocyte count 58,000/mm3
Platelet count 250,000/mm3
Flow cytometry on the peripheral blood reveals an absolute lymphocyte count of 50,000/mm3. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
(A) Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) (B) Monoclonal B cell lymphocytosis (MBL) (C) Monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS) (D) Multiple myeloma (MM)
A: Let's think step by step.

Q: A 75-year-old man presents to the physician for his annual blood pressure visit and blood work. He has no complaints other than occasional knee pain. Leukocyte count 58,000/mm3
Platelet count 250,000/mm3

options: (A) Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) (B) Monoclonal B cell lymphocytosis (MBL) (C) Monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS) (D) Multiple myeloma (MM)
outputs:

The patient's history and physical examination are consistent with monoclonal B cell lymphocytosis (MBL). The patient has a high absolute lymphocyte count, which is consistent with MBL. The patient's family history of hematologic malignancy increases the likelihood of MBL. The answer is (B).

Q: A 45-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of worsening right-sided abdominal pain. She has had similar episodes in the past, but this is the worst one yet. She denies any recent travel, sick contacts, or recent changes in her diet. She has no allergies. She has been taking ibuprofen as needed for pain control. She appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Abdominal examination shows guarding and tenderness to palpation over the right lower quadrant. There is no rebound tenderness or palpable mass. A stat abdominal plain film is obtained and shows an elevated right diaphragm. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Administer intravenous morphine (B) Administer intravenous ondansetron (C) Administer intravenous promethazine (D) Obtain a stat CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with IV contrast
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of similar episodes of abdominal pain in the past, but this is the worst one yet. She has been taking ibuprofen as needed for pain control. She appears uncomfortable. Abdominal examination shows guarding and tenderness to palpation over the right lower quadrant. There is no rebound tenderness or palpable mass. A stat abdominal plain film is obtained and shows an elevated right diaphragm. The patient's symptoms and physical examination are consistent with acute appendicitis. The patient needs immediate surgical intervention. The most appropriate next step in management is to obtain a stat CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with IV contrast to confirm the diagnosis. The answer is (D).

Q: Four weeks after starting hydrochlorothiazide, a 49-year-old man with hypertension comes to the physician because of muscle cramps and weakness. His home medications also include amlodipine. His blood pressure today is 176/87 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The precordial leads of a 12-lead ECG are shown. The addition of which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?
(A) Torsemide (B) Nifedipine (C) Eplerenone (D) Hydralazine
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has started hydrochlorothiazide. He now presents with muscle cramps and weakness and an ECG that supports the diagnosis of hypokalemia. The addition of (A) Torsemide is a loop diuretic and would likely aggravate the hypokalemia, (B) Nifedipine is a calcium antagonist and would not alleviate the hypocalcemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potassium-sparing diuretic and would likely decrease the chance of hypokalemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potent vasodilator and would not decrease the risk of hypokalemia. The answer is (C).

Q: A 57-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe pain around her right eye, blurred vision in the same eye, and a headache for the past 4 hours. She is nauseous but has not vomited. She can see colored bright circles when she looks at a light source. She is currently being treated for a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. She appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows visual acuity of 20/20 in the left eye and counting fingers at 5 feet in the right eye. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. Intravenous analgesia and antiemetics are administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Perform ultrasound biomicroscopy (B) Perform gonioscopy (C) Perform fundoscopy (D) Administer topical steroids
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has severe pain, blurred vision, and a headache. She is also nauseous but has not vomited. She can see bright colored circles when she looks at a light source. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. The tentative (most likely) diagnosis, given the patient's symptoms, is acute primary angle-closure glaucoma. Analgesics have been administered. The next step is to confirm the tentative diagnosis using the gold standard test. (A) ultrasound biomicroscopy could be used but are not widely available, (B) Gonioscopy is the gold-standard test to confirm the diagnosis of acute primary angle-closure glaucoma, (C) fundoscopy is not as reliable as gonioscopy, (D) topical steroids is not relevant, the possible medical therapy would be timolol, apraclonidine or pilocarpine. The most appropriate next step in management is to administer intravenous analgesia and antiemetics. The answer is (B).

Q: A 55-year-old man with a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia presents for follow-up 4 days into the treatment of a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. BUN 13 mg/dL

(A) Reassure the patient, stop trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and repeat the measurement in 1–2 weeks (B) Schedule an intravenous pyelography for urinary obstruction (C) Schedule a cystoscopy for urethral obstruction (D) Admit the patient for further management of acute interstitial nephritis
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia. These are both risk factors for urinary tract infections. Q: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles for the past 16 months. She began having symptoms of insomnia and depression 10 months ago. More recently, she has been having difficulties rising from a chair. She has a 2-year history of hypertension. Current medications include citalopram and hydrochlorothiazide. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb). BMI is 36 kg/m2. Her pulse is 92/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 134/76 mm Hg. She appears tired and has a full, plethoric face and central obesity. Examination of the skin shows violaceous linear striations on her lower abdomen. Two midnight serum cortisol studies show measurements of 288 μg/L and 253 μg/L (N < 90); a 24-hour urinary cortisol measurement was 395 μg (N < 300). Upon follow-up laboratory examination, the patient's serum ACTH levels were also elevated at 136 pg/mL (N = 7–50). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
(A) MRI of the head with contrast (B) Measure ACTH levels in inferior petrosal sinuses (C) High-dose dexamethasone suppression test (D) CT scan of the abdomen with contrast
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has Cushing's syndrome, which is characterized by weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles. She also has symptoms of insomnia and depression, which could be caused by Cushing's syndrome. Additionally, she has difficulties rising from a chair, which could be caused by muscle weakness. The two elevated serum cortisol measurements and the elevated ACTH levels confirm the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome. A high dose dexamethasone suppression test will help determine if the cause of Cushing's syndrome is Cushing's disease (CS caused by pituitary hypersecretion of ACTH) or ectopic ACTH syndrome (CS caused by nonpituitary ACTH-secreting tumors). Since the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome is established, the most appropriate next step is to distinguish between Cushing's disease and ectopic ACTH syndrome using the high-dose dexamethasone suppression test. The answer is (C).

A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a rash, fatigue, and pain in his wrists and ankles. Physical examination and symptoms are consistent with possible non-cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. The most likely associated diagnosis is Hepatitis C. The answer is (B).

outputs:

Q: A 35-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe left knee pain. She was playing soccer when she suddenly felt the pain. She is able to walk with a limp. There is severe tenderness to palpation over the patellar tendon. The patient is able to fully extend the knee, but there is moderate pain with flexion. There is no evidence of an effusion. The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings are consistent with a patellar tendinitis. The answer is (B).

Q: An 11-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother after she observed jerking movements of his arms and legs for about 30 seconds earlier that morning. He has not had fever, cough, or a runny nose. He has been healthy, except for occasional eczema. He was delivered at home in Romania. His mother had no prenatal care. She reports that he has required more time to reach developmental milestones compared to his older brother. The patient's immunization records are not available. He takes no medications. He appears pale with blue eyes and has a musty odor. He has poor eye contact. Which of the following would have most likely prevented the patient's symptoms?
(A) Levothyroxine therapy during pregnancy (B) Dietary restriction of phenylalanine (C) Daily allopurinol intake (D) Avoidance of fasting states
A: Let's think step by step.
question: Q: An 11-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother after she observed jerking movements of his arms and legs for about 30 seconds earlier that morning. He has not had fever, cough, or a runny nose. He has been healthy, except for occasional eczema. He was delivered at home in Romania. His mother had no prenatal care. She reports that he has required more time to reach developmental milestones compared to his older brother. The patient's immunization records are not available. He takes no medications. He appears pale with blue eyes and has a musty odor. He has poor eye contact. Which of the following would have most likely prevented the patient's symptoms?
options: (A) Levothyroxine therapy during pregnancy (B) Dietary restriction of phenylalanine (C) Daily allopurinol intake (D) Avoidance of fasting states
outputs:
The patient is 11 months old and has jerking movements of his arms and legs. He has no fever, cough, or runny nose. He has been healthy except for occasional eczema. He was delivered at home in Romania, and his mother had no prenatal care. The patient's immunization records are not available. He takes no medications. He appears pale with blue eyes and has a musty odor. He has poor eye contact. The patient's symptoms are consistent with phenylketonuria (PKU). PKU is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase, which is needed to break down phenylalanine, an amino acid found in many protein-containing foods. Without this enzyme, phenylalanine builds up in the blood and brain, leading to intellectual disability, seizures, and behavioral problems. The best way to prevent PKU is to restrict phenylalanine in the diet. Therefore, the answer is (B).

Q: A 27-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of fever, chills, and a nonproductive cough. She has recently returned from a 2-week trip to India. She has no significant medical history. She appears uncomfortable. Her temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a mildly tender abdomen with no rebound tenderness or guarding. There is no lymphadenopathy or organomegaly. A chest radiograph shows a right mid-lung lesion with cavitation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Sputum Gram stain (B) Bronchoscopy (C) CT scan of the chest with contrast (D) Empiric antituberculous therapy
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a fever, chills, and a nonproductive cough. She recently returned from a 2-week trip to India. She has no significant medical history. She appears uncomfortable. Her chest x-ray shows a right mid-lung lesion with cavitation. This is consistent with tuberculosis. The most appropriate next step in management would be to start empiric antituberculous therapy. The answer is (D).

A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a 6-month history of worsening shortness of breath, cough, and wheezing. Her chest x-ray shows marked lung hyperinflation and bilateral diffuse infiltrates. A high-resolution CT scan shows emphysema and bullae. This is consistent with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). The most appropriate next step in management would be to perform pulmonary function tests. The answer is (A).

Q: Four weeks after starting hydrochlorothiazide, a 49-year-old man with hypertension comes to the physician because of muscle cramps and weakness. His home medications also include amlodipine. His blood pressure today is 176/87 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The precordial leads of a 12-lead ECG are shown. The addition of which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?
(A) Torsemide (B) Nifedipine (C) Eplerenone (D) Hydralazine
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has started hydrochlorothiazide. He now presents with muscle cramps and weakness and an ECG that supports the diagnosis of hypokalemia. The addition of (A) Torsemide is a loop diuretic and would likely aggravate the hypokalemia, (B) Nifedipine is a calcium antagonist and would not alleviate the hypocalcemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potassium-sparing diuretic and would likely decrease the chance of hypokalemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potent vasodilator and would not decrease the risk of hypokalemia. The answer is (C).

Q: A 57-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe pain around her right eye, blurred vision in the same eye, and a headache for the past 4 hours. She is nauseous but has not vomited. She can see colored bright circles when she looks at a light source. She is currently being treated for a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. She appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows visual acuity of 20/20 in the left eye and counting fingers at 5 feet in the right eye. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. Intravenous analgesia and antiemetics are administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Perform ultrasound biomicroscopy (B) Perform gonioscopy (C) Perform fundoscopy (D) Administer topical steroids
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has severe pain, blurred vision, and a headache. She is also nauseous but has not vomited. She can see bright colored circles when she looks at a light source. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. The tentative (most likely) diagnosis, given the patient's symptoms, is acute primary angle-closure glaucoma. Analgesics have been administered. The next step is to confirm the tentative diagnosis using the gold standard test. (A) ultrasound biomicroscopy could be used but are not widely available, (B) Gonioscopy is the gold-standard test to confirm the diagnosis of acute primary angle-closure glaucoma, (C) fundoscopy is not as reliable as gonioscopy, (D) topical steroids is not relevant, the possible medical therapy would be timolol, apraclonidine or pilocarpine. The most appropriate next step in management is to administer intravenous analgesia and antiemetics. The answer is (B).

Q: A 55-year-old man with a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia presents for follow-up 4 days into the treatment of a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. His symptoms have resolved, and he reports no problems with urination, with the exception of a weak urine stream and hesitancy, which he has had for the past 2 years. At the time of this visit, the patient is afebrile; the blood pressure is 130/88 mm Hg and the heart rate is 80/min. There is no flank tenderness. A urinalysis reveals no leukocytes and is negative for esterase. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality:
Prior treatment
BUN 12 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL
Today’s visit
BUN 13 mg/dL
Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL
(A) Reassure the patient, stop trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and repeat the measurement in 1–2 weeks (B) Schedule an intravenous pyelography for urinary obstruction (C) Schedule a cystoscopy for urethral obstruction (D) Admit the patient for further management of acute interstitial nephritis
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia. These are both risk factors for urinary tract infections. The patient is being treated with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for a urinary tract infection. The symptoms have resolved, but the patient has a weak urine stream and hesitancy. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality: BUN 12 mg/dL, Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL (prior treatment) vs BUN 13 mg/dL, Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL (today’s visit). The BUN and creatinine levels have increased from the prior visit. This could be due to acute interstitial nephritis. A known but rare side effect of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Interstitial nephritis should be suspected if there is an elevated creatinine and a urinalysis that shows white cells, white cell casts, and, in some cases, eosinophiluria. Since none of the urinalysis results is present and the patient has no typical symptoms such as fever, rash, or acute interstitial nephritis is an unlikely diagnosis. The answer is (A).

Q: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles for the past 16 months. She began having symptoms of insomnia and depression 10 months ago. More recently, she has been having difficulties rising from a chair. She has a 2-year history of hypertension. Current medications include citalopram and hydrochlorothiazide. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb). BMI is 36 kg/m2. Her pulse is 92/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 134/76 mm Hg. She appears tired and has a full, plethoric face and central obesity. Examination of the skin shows violaceous linear striations on her lower abdomen. Two midnight serum cortisol studies show measurements of 288 μg/L and 253 μg/L (N < 90); a 24-hour urinary cortisol measurement was 395 μg (N < 300). Upon follow-up laboratory examination, the patient's serum ACTH levels were also elevated at 136 pg/mL (N = 7–50). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
(A) MRI of the head with contrast (B) Measure ACTH levels in inferior petrosal sinuses (C) High-dose dexamethasone suppression test (D) CT scan of the abdomen with contrast
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has Cushing's syndrome, which is characterized by weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles. She also has symptoms of insomnia and depression, which could be caused by Cushing's syndrome. Additionally, she has difficulties rising from a chair, which could be caused by muscle weakness. The two elevated serum cortisol measurements and the elevated ACTH levels confirm the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome. A high dose dexamethasone suppression test will help determine if the cause of Cushing's syndrome is Cushing's disease (CS caused by pituitary hypersecretion of ACTH) or ectopic ACTH syndrome (CS caused by nonpituitary ACTH-secreting tumors). Since the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome is established, the most appropriate next step is to distinguish between Cushing's disease and ectopic ACTH syndrome using the high-dose dexamethasone suppression test. The answer is (C).

Q: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a nonpruritic rash. He has been feeling more tired than usual and occasionally experiences pain in his wrists and ankles. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows multiple, erythematous, purpuric papules on his trunk and extremities that do not blanch when pressed. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The patient's hemoglobin is 14 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9,500/mm3, and platelet count is 228,000/mm3. Urinalysis and liver function tests are within normal limits. The test for rheumatoid factor is positive. Serum ANA is negative. Serum complement levels are decreased. Serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation shows increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. Testing for cryoglobulins shows no precipitate after 24 hours. Chest x-ray and ECG show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Rapid plasma reagin test (B) Hepatitis C serology (C) pANCA assay (D) Bence Jones protein test
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a rash, fatigue, and pain in his wrists and ankles. He has normal hemoglobin (normal range 13.8-17.2 g/dL), normal leukocyte count (normal range 4500-11000 wbc/microliter), and normal platelet count (normal range 150-450 platelets/microliter). His serum complement levels are decreased. His serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation show increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. The cryoglobulin precipitation test is normal, ruling out cryoglobulinemia. Serum ANA is negative, so Lupus is less likely. Physical examination and symptoms are consistent with possible non-cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. The most likely associated diagnosis is Hepatitis C. The answer is (B).

Q: A researcher hypothesizes that low birth weight is related to obesity later in life. He conducts a study with a 95% confidence interval with a p-value of 0.049 to disprove his null hypothesis. He rejects his null hypothesis and concludes that low birth weight is associated with obesity. Which of the following statements best associates with his study?
(A) Confidence interval should have been 90%. (B) A type 2 error is not possible in this case. (C) A type 2 error has been made. (D) A type 1 error has been made.
A: Let's think step by step.
question: Q: A researcher hypothesizes that low birth weight is related to obesity later in life. He conducts a study with a 95% confidence interval with a p-value of 0.049 to disprove his null hypothesis. He rejects his null hypothesis and concludes that low birth weight is associated with obesity. Which of the following statements best associates with his study?
options: (A) Confidence interval should have been 90%. (B) A type 2 error is not possible in this case. (C) A type 2 error has been made. (D) A type 1 error has been made.
outputs:
The researcher has conducted a study to determine if low birth weight is related to obesity later in life. He has used a 95% confidence interval with a p-value of 0.049 to disprove his null hypothesis. This means that there is a 5% chance that the observed association between low birth weight and obesity is due to chance. If the p-value is less than 0.05, the null hypothesis is rejected, and it suggests that low birth weight is associated with obesity. In this case, the null hypothesis is rejected, so a type 1 error has been made. The answer is (D).

Q: A 45-year-old woman is evaluated for a 6-month history of worsening left knee pain. She has no history of knee injury or surgery. She has tried physical therapy and analgesics without significant relief. She is currently taking naproxen. She appears healthy and has a normal gait. The knee is swollen and tender to palpation. There is no erythema or warmth. The patient walks with a cane and has limited mobility. The patient's blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg, pulse is 70/min, and respirations are 18/min. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Arthrocentesis (B) Intra-articular corticosteroid injection (C) Knee radiographs (D) Magnetic resonance imaging of the knee
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has worsening left knee pain that has not responded to physical therapy and analgesics. She has tried naproxen and has a normal gait, but her knee is swollen and tender to palpation. There is no erythema or warmth. Given the patient's symptoms and physical examination findings, the most likely diagnosis is osteoarthritis. The next step in management would be to confirm the diagnosis with imaging studies. Knee radiographs would be the most appropriate next step in management. The answer is (C).

The next step in management would be to confirm the diagnosis with imaging studies. Shoulder radiographs would be the most appropriate next step in management. The answer is (C).

The answer is (C).

Q: A 57-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe pain around her right eye, blurred vision in the same eye, and a headache for the past 4 hours. She is nauseous but has not vomited. She can see colored bright circles when she looks at a light source. She is currently being treated for a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. She appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows visual acuity of 20/20 in the left eye and counting fingers at 5 feet in the right eye. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. Intravenous analgesia and antiemetics are administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Perform ultrasound biomicroscopy (B) Perform gonioscopy (C) Perform fundoscopy (D) Administer topical steroids
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has severe pain, blurred vision, and a headache. She is also nauseous but has not vomited. She can see bright colored circles when she looks at a light source. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. The tentative (most likely) diagnosis, given the patient's symptoms, is acute primary angle-closure glaucoma. Analgesics have been administered. The next step is to confirm the tentative diagnosis using the gold standard test. (A) ultrasound biomicroscopy could be used but are not widely available, (B) Gonioscopy is the gold-standard test to confirm the diagnosis of acute primary angle-closure glaucoma, (C) fundoscopy is not as reliable as gonioscopy, (D) topical steroids is not relevant, the possible medical therapy would be timolol, apraclonidine or pilocarpine. The most appropriate next step in management is to administer intravenous analgesia and antiemetics. The answer is (B).

Q: A 55-year-old man with a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia presents for follow-up 4 days into the treatment of a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. His symptoms have resolved, and he reports no problems with urination, with the exception of a weak urine stream and hesitancy, which he has had for the past 2 years. At the time of this visit, the patient is afebrile; the blood pressure is 130/88 mm Hg and the heart rate is 80/min. There is no flank tenderness. A urinalysis reveals no leukocytes and is negative for esterase. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality:
Prior treatment
BUN 12 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL
Today’s visit
BUN 13 mg/dL
Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL
(A) Reassure the patient, stop trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and repeat the measurement in 1–2 weeks (B) Schedule an intravenous pyelography for urinary obstruction (C) Schedule a cystoscopy for urethral obstruction (D) Admit the patient for further management of acute interstitial nephritis
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia. These are both risk factors for urinary tract infections. The patient is being treated with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for a urinary tract infection. The symptoms have resolved, but the patient has a weak urine stream and hesitancy. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality: BUN 12 mg/dL, Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL (prior treatment) vs BUN 13 mg/dL, Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL (today’s visit). Since none of the urinalysis results is present and the patient has no typical symptoms such as fever, rash, or acute interstitial nephritis is an unlikely diagnosis. The answer is (A).

Q: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles for the past 16 months. She began having symptoms of insomnia and depression 10 months ago. More recently, she has been having difficulties rising from a chair. She has a 2-year history of hypertension. Current medications include citalopram and hydrochlorothiazide. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb). BMI is 36 kg/m2. Her pulse is 92/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 134/76 mm Hg. She appears tired and has a full, plethoric face and central obesity. Examination of the skin shows violaceous linear striations on her lower abdomen. Two midnight serum cortisol studies show measurements of 288 μg/L and 253 μg/L (N < 90); a 24-hour urinary cortisol measurement was 395 μg (N < 300). Upon follow-up laboratory examination, the patient's serum ACTH levels were also elevated at 136 pg/mL (N = 7–50). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
(A) MRI of the head with contrast (B) Measure ACTH levels in inferior petrosal sinuses (C) High-dose dexamethasone suppression test (D) CT scan of the abdomen with contrast
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has Cushing's syndrome, which is characterized by weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles. She also has symptoms of insomnia and depression, which could be caused by Cushing's syndrome. Additionally, she has difficulties rising from a chair, which could be caused by muscle weakness. The two elevated serum cortisol measurements and the elevated ACTH levels confirm the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome. A high dose dexamethasone suppression test will help determine if the cause of Cushing's syndrome is Cushing's disease (CS caused by pituitary hypersecretion of ACTH) or ectopic ACTH syndrome (CS caused by nonpituitary ACTH-secreting tumors). Since the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome is established, the most appropriate next step is to distinguish between Cushing's disease and ectopic ACTH syndrome using the high-dose dexamethasone suppression test. The answer is (C).

Q: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a nonpruritic rash. He has been feeling more tired than usual and occasionally experiences pain in his wrists and ankles. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows multiple, erythematous, purpuric papules on his trunk and extremities that do not blanch when pressed. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The patient's hemoglobin is 14 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9,500/mm3, and platelet count is 228,000/mm3. Urinalysis and liver function tests are within normal limits. The test for rheumatoid factor is positive. Serum ANA is negative. Serum complement levels are decreased. Serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation shows increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. Testing for cryoglobulins shows no precipitate after 24 hours. Chest x-ray and ECG show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Rapid plasma reagin test (B) Hepatitis C serology (C) pANCA assay (D) Bence Jones protein test
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a rash, fatigue, and pain in his wrists and ankles. He has normal hemoglobin (normal range 13.8-17.2 g/dL), normal leukocyte count (normal range 4500-11000 wbc/microliter), and normal platelet count (normal range 150-450 platelets/microliter). His serum complement levels are decreased. His serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation show increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. The cryoglobulin precipitation test is normal, ruling out cryoglobulinemia. Serum ANA is negative, so Lupus is less likely. Physical examination and symptoms are consistent with possible non-cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. The most likely associated diagnosis is Hepatitis C. The answer is (B).

Q: A 3-week-old newborn is brought to the physician by his parents because of poor feeding, irritability, and frequent vomiting over the past week. The vomitus is greenish in color and smells strange. His parents have tried to feed him every 4 hours, but the patient often spits up or refuses to eat. The patient was born at term and had his first bowel movement at 50 hours of life. He has since had one bowel movement daily. He is at the 50th percentile for length, 10th percentile for weight, and 40th percentile for head circumference. He does not appear to be in acute distress. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 40/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Physical examination shows that the patient has small, low-set ears, a broad and flat nasal bridge, and a large space between the first and second toes bilaterally. The abdomen is distended. When the finger is removed following a rectal exam, there is an explosive release of stool from the patient's rectum. An x-ray of the abdomen shows a section of dilated colon followed by a segment of colon without stool or air. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
(A) CT scan of the abdomen (B) Transabdominal ultrasonography (C) Anorectal manometry (D) Rectal suction biopsy
A: Let's think step by step.
question: Q: A 3-week-old newborn is brought to the physician by his parents because of poor feeding, irritability, and frequent vomiting over the past week. The vomitus is greenish in color and smells strange. His parents have tried to feed him every 4 hours, but the patient often spits up or refuses to eat. The patient was born at term and had his first bowel movement at 50 hours of life. He has since had one bowel movement daily. He is at the 50th percentile for length, 10th percentile for weight, and 40th percentile for head circumference. He does not appear to be in acute distress. An x-ray of the abdomen shows a section of dilated colon followed by a segment of colon without stool or air. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?

outputs:
The patient is 3 weeks old and has symptoms of poor feeding, irritability, and frequent vomiting. The vomitus is greenish in color and smells strange. The patient was born at term and had his first bowel movement at 50 hours of life. He has since had one bowel movement daily. The patient has small, low-set ears, a broad and flat nasal bridge, and a large space between the first and second toes bilaterally. The abdomen is distended. An x-ray of the abdomen shows a section of dilated colon followed by a segment of colon without stool or air. The most likely diagnosis is Hirschsprung's disease, a congenital disorder that affects the large intestine. It is characterized by a lack of ganglion cells in the distal portion of the colon, which leads to constipation and abdominal distension. The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings support this diagnosis. The next step in management would be to confirm the diagnosis using a test that can visualize the colon and show the absence of ganglion cells. The answer is (B).

Q: A 68-year-old man with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia comes to the emergency department because of acute onset of severe headache, blurred vision, and difficulty speaking. He is currently taking lisinopril, atorvastatin, and aspirin. He appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a blood pressure of 210/110 mm Hg, irregular heart rate of 120/min, and respirations of 20/min. The patient's speech is slurred, and he has difficulty answering questions. A neurological examination shows no abnormalities. The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings are consistent with a hypertensive emergency. The patient's blood pressure is dangerously high and must be lowered immediately. The most appropriate next step in management would be to administer intravenous medication to lower the patient's blood pressure. The answer is (B).

Q: A 28-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of fever, chills, and a nonproductive cough. She has been feeling tired and has had night sweats. Q: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of progressive left leg pain for 2 months, which has started to interfere with his sleep. His mother has been giving him ibuprofen at night for “growing pains,” but his symptoms have not improved. One week before the pain started, the patient was hit in the thigh by a baseball, which caused his leg to become red and swollen for several days. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows marked tenderness along the left mid-femur. His gait is normal. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 21,000/mm3 and an ESR of 68 mm/h. An x-ray of the left lower extremity shows multiple lytic lesions in the middle third of the femur, and the surrounding cortex is covered by several layers of new bone. A biopsy of the left femur shows small round blue cells. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
(A) Osteosarcoma (B) Osteochondroma (C) Ewing sarcoma (D) Osteoid osteoma
A: Let's think step by step.
question: Q: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of progressive left leg pain for 2 months, which has started to interfere with his sleep. His mother has been giving him ibuprofen at night for “growing pains,” but his symptoms have not improved. One week before the pain started, the patient was hit in the thigh by a baseball, which caused his leg to become red and swollen for several days. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows marked tenderness along the left mid-femur. His gait is normal. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 21,000/mm3 and an ESR of 68 mm/h. An x-ray of the left lower extremity shows multiple lytic lesions in the middle third of the femur, and the surrounding cortex is covered by several layers of new bone. A biopsy of the left femur shows small round blue cells. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
options: (A) Osteosarcoma (B) Osteochondroma (C) Ewing sarcoma (D) Osteoid osteoma
outputs:
The patient is a 13-year-old boy who has been experiencing progressive left leg pain for 2 months. The pain started after he was hit in the thigh by a baseball, which caused his leg to become red and swollen for several days. The patient's vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows marked tenderness along the left mid-femur, and his gait is normal. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 21,000/mm3 and an ESR of 68 mm/h. An x-ray of the left lower extremity shows multiple lytic lesions in the middle third of the femur, and the surrounding cortex is covered by several layers of new bone. A biopsy of the left femur shows small round blue cells. The patient's symptoms, physical examination findings, laboratory results, and imaging studies are consistent with a bone tumor. The most likely diagnosis is Ewing sarcoma. The answer is (C).

Q: A 67-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of sudden onset of severe substernal pain that radiates to his left arm. He has a history of hypertension and smokes one pack of cigarettes per day. His temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 180/110 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a well-developed man with marked obesity. There is a 4/6 systolic murmur at the left lower sternal border. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Electrocardiography shows ST-segment elevation in leads V3 through V6. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Administer sublingual nitroglycerin (B) Administer intravenous furosemide (C) Administer intravenous metoprolol (D) Perform cardiac catheterization
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension and smokes one pack of cigarettes per day. He presents with sudden onset of severe substernal pain that radiates to his left arm. His blood pressure is 180/110 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a well-developed man with marked obesity. There is a 4/6 systolic murmur at the left lower sternal border. Electrocardiography shows ST-segment elevation in leads V3 through V6. The patient's symptoms, physical examination findings, and electrocardiography results are consistent with an acute coronary syndrome. The most appropriate next step in management is to administer intravenous metoprolol. The answer is (C).
