Q: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles for the past 16 months. She began having symptoms of insomnia and depression 10 months ago. More recently, she has been having difficulties rising from a chair. She has a 2-year history of hypertension. Current medications include citalopram and hydrochlorothiazide. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb). BMI is 36 kg/m2. Her pulse is 92/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 134/76 mm Hg. She appears tired and has a full, plethoric face and central obesity. Examination of the skin shows violaceous linear striations on her lower abdomen. Two midnight serum cortisol studies show measurements of 288 μg/L and 253 μg/L (N < 90); a 24-hour urinary cortisol measurement was 395 μg (N < 300). Upon follow-up laboratory examination, the patient's serum ACTH levels were also elevated at 136 pg/mL (N = 7–50). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
(A) MRI of the head with contrast (B) Measure ACTH levels in inferior petrosal sinuses (C) High-dose dexamethasone suppression test (D) CT scan of the abdomen with contrast
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has Cushing's syndrome, which is characterized by weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles. She also has symptoms of insomnia and depression, which could be caused by Cushing's syndrome. Additionally, she has difficulties rising from a chair, which could be caused by muscle weakness. The two elevated serum cortisol measurements and the elevated ACTH levels confirm the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome. A high dose dexamethasone suppression test will help determine if the cause of Cushing's syndrome is Cushing's disease (CS caused by pituitary hypersecretion of ACTH) or ectopic ACTH syndrome (CS caused by nonpituitary ACTH-secreting tumors). Since the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome is established, the most appropriate next step is to distinguish between Cushing's disease and ectopic ACTH syndrome using the high-dose dexamethasone suppression test. The answer is (C).

Q: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a nonpruritic rash. He has been feeling more tired than usual and occasionally experiences pain in his wrists and ankles. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows multiple, erythematous, purpuric papules on his trunk and extremities that do not blanch when pressed. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The patient's hemoglobin is 14 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9,500/mm3, and platelet count is 228,000/mm3. Urinalysis and liver function tests are within normal limits. The test for rheumatoid factor is positive. Serum ANA is negative. Serum complement levels are decreased. Serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation shows increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. Testing for cryoglobulins shows no precipitate after 24 hours. Chest x-ray and ECG show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Rapid plasma reagin test (B) Hepatitis C serology (C) pANCA assay (D) Bence Jones protein test
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a rash, fatigue, and pain in his wrists and ankles. He has normal hemoglobin (normal range 13.8-17.2 g/dL), normal leukocyte count (normal range 4500-11000 wbc/microliter), and normal platelet count (normal range 150-450 platelets/microliter). His serum complement levels are decreased. His serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation show increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. The cryoglobulin precipitation test is normal, ruling out cryoglobulinemia. Serum ANA is negative, so Lupus is less likely. Physical examination and symptoms are consistent with possible non-cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. The most likely associated diagnosis is Hepatitis C. The answer is (B).

Q: A 55-year-old male with a history of stage I colon cancer status-post left hemicolectomy presents to your office for follow-up. You intend to discuss the results from his recent surveillance colonoscopy, which showed no remaining cancer, no polyps, and a well-healed anastmosis. During your meeting, you note that the patient is exhibiting the defense mechanism of suppression. Which of the following statements from the patient is consistent with your impression?
(A) "Last week I volunteered for the local Cancer Society. Helping other cancer patients just makes me feel better." (B) "Oh, doctor, I'm just so grateful to be seeing you. I just know you've cured my cancer. I probably don't even need to check anymore." (C) "I'm sorry I was late today. I also didn't get any of the labs you asked for." (D) "I really haven't thought about the colonoscopy until today. Worrying before getting the results wasn't going to help anything."
A: Let's think step by step.
question: Q: A 55-year-old male with a history of stage I colon cancer status-post left hemicolectomy presents to your office for follow-up. options: (A) "Last week I volunteered for the local Cancer Society. Helping other cancer patients just makes me feel better." (B) "Oh, doctor, I'm just so grateful to be seeing you. outputs:

Q: A 45-year-old woman with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and obesity (BMI 34 kg/m2) presents to the emergency department with acute onset left-sided chest pain and difficulty speaking. Her blood pressure is 180/105 mm Hg, heart rate is 110/min, and respirations are 24/min. Physical examination shows a drooping of the left eyelid, difficulty moving the left arm and leg, and slurred speech. The patient is unable to complete the sentence "The sky is blue." Laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 18,000/mm3, hemoglobin 12 g/dL, hematocrit 36%, platelet count 200,000/mm3, and electrolyte levels within normal limits. A 12-lead ECG shows ST-segment elevation in leads V1 through V6. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Administer intravenous tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) (B) Administer sublingual nitroglycerin (C) Perform an urgent computed tomography (CT) scan of the brain (D) Perform an urgent coronary angiogram
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and obesity. She presents with acute onset left-sided chest pain and difficulty speaking. Her blood pressure is elevated, and physical examination shows a drooping of the left eyelid, difficulty moving the left arm and leg, and slurred speech. The patient is unable to complete the sentence "The sky is blue." The patient is showing signs of a stroke. A 12-lead ECG shows ST-segment elevation in leads V1 through V6, which suggests a myocardial infarction. The patient needs immediate treatment for the myocardial infarction. The most appropriate next step in management is to administer intravenous tissue plasminogen activator (tPA). The answer is (A).

A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and smoking. She presents with a 2-day history of worsening left-sided chest pain and shortness of breath. Her blood pressure is elevated, and physical examination shows a drooping of the left eyelid, difficulty moving the left arm and leg, and slurred speech. The patient is unable to complete the sentence "The sky is blue." A 12-lead ECG shows ST-segment elevation in leads V1 through V6, which suggests a myocardial infarction. The patient needs immediate treatment for the myocardial infarction

Q: Four weeks after starting hydrochlorothiazide, a 49-year-old man with hypertension comes to the physician because of muscle cramps and weakness. His home medications also include amlodipine. His blood pressure today is 176/87 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The precordial leads of a 12-lead ECG are shown. The addition of which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?
(A) Torsemide (B) Nifedipine (C) Eplerenone (D) Hydralazine
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has started hydrochlorothiazide. He now presents with muscle cramps and weakness and an ECG that supports the diagnosis of hypokalemia. The addition of (A) Torsemide is a loop diuretic and would likely aggravate the hypokalemia, (B) Nifedipine is a calcium antagonist and would not alleviate the hypocalcemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potassium-sparing diuretic and would likely decrease the chance of hypokalemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potent vasodilator and would not decrease the risk of hypokalemia. The answer is (C).

Q: A 57-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe pain around her right eye, blurred vision in the same eye, and a headache for the past 4 hours. The most appropriate next step in management is to administer intravenous analgesia and antiemetics. The answer is (B).

Q: A 67-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with severe, crushing, retrosternal chest pain for the last 45 minutes. The pain radiates to his left shoulder and is associated with sweating. The past medical history is significant for hypercholesterolemia, for which he takes lovastatin. He smoked as a youth but quit at 40 years of age. On arrival at the emergency department, the vital signs were as follows: pulse 58/min, respiratory rate 22/min, and blood pressure 90/56 mm Hg. He is sweating profusely. The jugular venous pulse is visible 2.5 cm above the sternal angle. Auscultation reveals soft S1 and S2 heart sounds with an added S4 and bilateral inspiratory crackles at the lung bases. The electrocardiogram shows ST-elevations in leads V1 and V2. A diagnosis of an anteroseptal infarction is made. The patient was given aspirin on the way to the hospital. He is started on dopamine, morphine, nitroglycerin, and streptokinase. Which of the following would be the most concerning development over the next 24h this patient?
(A) Hemoptysis (B) Easy fatigability (C) Persistent ST-segment elevation (D) Shortness of breath
A: Let's think step by step.
question: Q: A 67-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with severe, crushing, retrosternal chest pain for the last 45 minutes. The pain radiates to his left shoulder and is associated with sweating. The past medical history is significant for hypercholesterolemia, for which he takes lovastatin. He smoked as a youth but quit at 40 years of age. On arrival at the emergency department, the vital signs were as follows: pulse 58/min, respiratory rate 22/min, and blood pressure 90/56 mm Hg. He is sweating profusely. The jugular venous pulse is visible 2.5 cm above the sternal angle. Auscultation reveals soft S1 and S2 heart sounds with an added S4 and bilateral inspiratory crackles at the lung bases. The electrocardiogram shows ST-elevations in leads V1 and V2. A diagnosis of an anteroseptal infarction is made. The patient was given aspirin on the way to the hospital. He is started on dopamine, morphine, nitroglycerin, and streptokinase. Which of the following would be the most concerning development over the next 24h this patient?
options: (A) Hemoptysis (B) Easy fatigability (C) Persistent ST-segment elevation (D) Shortness of breath
outputs:
The patient has a history of hypercholesterolemia and smoking, which are risk factors for coronary artery disease. He presents with severe, crushing, retrosternal chest pain that radiates to his left shoulder and is associated with sweating. The patient's vital signs show a low blood pressure of 90/56 mm Hg, which is concerning. The physical examination shows jugular venous distension, soft S1 and S2 heart sounds with an added S4, and bilateral inspiratory crackles at the lung bases. The electrocardiogram shows ST-elevations in leads V1 and V2, consistent with an anteroseptal infarction. The patient has been started on aspirin, dopamine, morphine, nitroglycerin, and streptokinase. Over the next 24 hours, the most concerning development would be shortness of breath. The patient's chest pain and ST-elevations on the electrocardiogram suggest a myocardial infarction, which can lead to cardiac failure and shortness of breath. The patient's age and history of smoking also increase the risk of cardiac complications. Therefore, close monitoring of the patient's respiratory status and cardiac function is crucial. The answer is (D).

Q: A 34-year-old woman comes to the clinic because of a 2-year history of progressive weakness and fatigue. She also has a 1-year history of intermittent numbness and tingling of the hands and feet. She has been taking oral contraceptives for 5 years. She is currently taking ethinyl estradiol and norgestimate. She has no history of neurological disease or recent significant weight loss. On physical examination, there is mild proximal muscle weakness. Muscle strength is normal. Deep tendon reflexes are normal. Plantar reflexes are flexor. There is no sensory loss. The patient has a normal MRI of the brain and spinal cord. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Electromyography (B) Nerve conduction studies (C) 24-hour Holter monitor (D) High-dose vitamin supplementation
A: Let's think step by step. The patient presents with a 2-year history of progressive weakness and fatigue, as well as a 1-year history of intermittent numbness and tingling of the hands and feet. She has been taking oral contraceptives for 5 years. The patient has mild proximal muscle weakness and normal deep tendon reflexes, but no sensory loss. The MRI of the brain and spinal cord is normal. The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings are consistent with a peripheral neuropathy. The most appropriate next step in management would be nerve conduction studies. Nerve conduction studies are diagnostic tests that evaluate the function of the peripheral nerves. They can help determine the extent and severity of the neuropathy, as well as the type of neuropathy present. Electromyography (EMG) may also be considered to evaluate the electrical activity of the muscles, but nerve conduction studies are more appropriate for the patient's symptoms. The answer is (B).

Q: A 42-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of sudden onset of severe, substernal pain radiating to the left arm and jaw. The pain is exacerbated by inspiration and associated with shortness of breath. The patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Physical examination shows jugular venous distension. There is a 2/6 systolic murmur at the apex. There is no evidence of a pulmonary embolus. An ECG shows ST elevation in leads V1 to V6. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A: Let's think step by step. The patient

question: Q: A 65-year-old male presents to his pulmonologist for a follow-up visit. He has a history of chronic progressive dyspnea over the past five years. outputs:
The patient has a history of chronic progressive dyspnea over the past five years. He uses oxygen at home and has a history of hyperlipidemia and hypertension. His smoking history is 45 pack-years. The patient is likely to have chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). The medication that has both mucoactive and anti-oxidative properties is likely to be an anticholinergic bronchodilator. Q: Four weeks after starting hydrochlorothiazide, a 49-year-old man with hypertension comes to the physician because of muscle cramps and weakness. His home medications also include amlodipine. A: Let's think step by step. The patient has started hydrochlorothiazide. He now presents with muscle cramps and weakness and an ECG that supports the diagnosis of hypokalemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potassium-sparing diuretic and would likely decrease the chance of hypokalemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potent vasodilator and would not decrease the risk of hypokalemia. The answer is (C).

Q: A 57-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe pain around her right eye, blurred vision in the same eye, and a headache for the past 4 hours. A: Let's think step by step. The patient has severe pain, blurred vision, and a headache. She is also nauseous but has not vomited. Q: A 55-year-old man with a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia presents for follow-up 4 days into the treatment of a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Q: A 36-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, at 42 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for induction of labor. Her pregnancy has been uncomplicated. Her two other children were born after uncomplicated vaginal deliveries at 41 and 42 weeks' gestation, respectively. Her only medication is a prenatal vitamin. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 86 kg (200 lb); BMI is 33 kg/m2. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.4°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 110/80 mmHg. Examination shows a nontender, soft uterus consistent in size with a 42-weeks' gestation. This patient's child is at greatest risk for which of the following complications?
(A) Polyhydramnios (B) Acute respiratory distress syndrome (C) Meconium aspiration (D) Placental abruption
A: Let's think step by step.
question: Q: A 36-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, at 42 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for induction of labor. Her pregnancy has been uncomplicated. Her two other children were born after uncomplicated vaginal deliveries at 41 and 42 weeks' gestation, respectively. Her only medication is a prenatal vitamin. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 86 kg (200 lb); BMI is 33 kg/m2. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.4°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 110/80 mmHg. Examination shows a nontender, soft uterus consistent in size with a 42-weeks' gestation. This patient's child is at greatest risk for which of the following complications?
options: (A) Polyhydramnios (B) Acute respiratory distress syndrome (C) Meconium aspiration (D) Placental abruption
outputs:
The patient is at 42 weeks' gestation, which puts the child at risk for complications related to prolonged gestation. The patient's history of uncomplicated vaginal deliveries at 41 and 42 weeks' gestation, respectively, suggests that she may have a history of prolonged labor. The patient's current pregnancy has been uncomplicated, which suggests that the risk of acute complications such as placental abruption or acute respiratory distress syndrome is low. The patient's BMI of 33 kg/m2 suggests that she may be at increased risk for gestational diabetes, but this is not a direct risk factor for the child. The patient's nontender, soft uterus suggests that the risk of uterine rupture is low. The child is at greatest risk for (C) meconium aspiration. Meconium aspiration occurs when the fetus inhales a mixture of meconium and amniotic fluid during delivery, which can cause respiratory distress. The risk of meconium aspiration increases with prolonged gestation, as the fetus may pass meconium in utero. The answer is (C).

Q: A 36-year-old man with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and obesity (BMI 31 kg/m2) is evaluated for a 2-week history of worsening left knee pain. He describes the pain as a constant, dull ache that is aggravated by activity and relieved by rest. The pain is localized to the medial aspect of the knee, and there is no associated swelling or erythema. He denies any recent trauma or injuries. He has tried over-the-counter pain medications without significant relief. He has no known allergies and is currently taking lisinopril, simvastatin, and hydrochlorothiazide. On physical examination, the patient's vital signs are normal. The knee is mildly swollen and tender to palpation over the medial aspect. There is no evidence of effusion or warmth. The patient has a mild limp. The remainder of the musculoskeletal examination is normal. The patient's serum creatine kinase level is normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Order an MRI of the knee (B) Order an ultrasound of the knee (C) Administer intra-articular corticosteroids (D) Prescribe physical therapy
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and obesity. He has been experiencing worsening left knee pain for 2 weeks, which is a constant, dull ache that is aggravated by activity and relieved by rest. The pain is localized to the medial aspect of the knee, and there is no associated swelling or erythema. The patient has tried over-the-counter pain medications without significant relief. The patient's vital signs are normal, and the knee is mildly swollen and tender to palpation over the medial aspect. There is no evidence of effusion or warmth, and the patient has a mild limp. The remainder of the musculoskeletal examination is normal. The patient's serum creatine kinase level is normal. The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings are consistent with osteoarthritis. The most appropriate next step in management is to order an MRI of the knee to confirm the diagnosis and assess the severity of the condition. The answer is (A).

Q: A 47-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by paramedics. She was found unconscious on a park bench by a bystander. Her history is unobtainable. Vitals include a pulse of 64/min, a respiratory rate of 7/min, and a blood pressure of 110/70 mm Hg. On examination, the patient is unresponsive to voice and touch but shows a flexor response to pain. Her breathing is shallow. The pupils are constricted, and a response to light cannot be determined. An arterial blood gas sample reveals:
pH 7.26
Pco2 70 mm Hg
HCO3-  26 mEq/L
Which of the following could explain this patient's presentation?
options: (A) Diabetic ketoacidosis (B) Diuretic overdose (C) Hyperventilation (D) Opioid overdose
outputs:
The patient is unconscious, has a slow respiratory rate, and shallow breathing. The arterial blood gas sample shows a Pco2 of 70 mm Hg, which is very high. This could indicate hyperventilation. The patient's presentation could be explained by hyperventilation, which is a common complication of diabetic ketoacidosis. The answer is (C).

Q: A 27-year-old woman comes to the clinic because of a 6-month history of amenorrhea. She denies any recent illnesses, medication use, or changes in her diet. She has not had any recent vaginal bleeding or spotting. She has been sexually active with her boyfriend, using no form of contraception. Her last menstrual period was 6 months ago. She has been trying to conceive for the past 3 months. Physical examination shows a blood pressure of 118/76 mm Hg, a pulse of 72/min, and a respiratory rate of 18/min. The patient's body mass index is 24 kg/m2. Examination of the breasts, abdomen, and pelvis shows no abnormalities. A vaginal ultrasound shows a normal uterus and ovaries. The patient's serum follicle-stimulating hormone level is 15 mIU/mL. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
(A) Polycystic ovary syndrome (B) Hypothyroidism (C) Hyperprolactinemia (D) Premature ovarian failure
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has amenorrhea for 6 months, which could be caused by several factors, including polycystic ovary syndrome, hypothyroidism, hyperprolactinemia, and premature ovarian failure. The patient's follicle-stimulating hormone level is 15 mIU/mL, which is within the normal range. This suggests that the patient's ovaries are still functioning normally. The patient's body mass index is 24 kg/m2, which is not consistent with polycystic ovary syndrome. The patient has no symptoms of hypothyroidism, such as cold intolerance, constipation, or fatigue. The patient's prolactin level is not elevated, ruling out hyperprolactinemia. The patient's age and menstrual history suggest that premature ovarian failure is the most likely diagnosis. The answer is (D).

Q: A 35-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of worsening headache, fever, nausea, and vomiting. She has been treated for migraines in the past but states that these symptoms are much worse than her usual migraines. She appears uncomfortable. Temperature is 38.9°C (102.0°F), pulse is 112/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 126/82 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a mild occipital-frontal headache with no other focal neurological deficits. There is no meningism. The patient's complete blood count shows a white blood cell count of 12,000/mm3, with 82% segmented neutrophils. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Administer intravenous ceftriaxone and metronidazole (B) Perform a lumbar puncture (C) Order a CT scan of the head (D) Administer intravenous vancomycin
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a fever, headache, nausea, and vomiting, which could be caused by several factors, including meningitis. The patient's complete blood count shows a white blood cell count of 12,000/mm3, with 82% segmented neutrophils, which suggests that the patient has a bacterial infection. The patient's symptoms are worse than her usual migraines, and she has no focal neurological deficits or meningism. The most appropriate next step in management would be to administer intravenous ceftriaxone and metronidazole to cover possible bacter

The following are multiple choice questions (with answers) about professional medicine.

Q: Four weeks after starting hydrochlorothiazide, a 49-year-old man with hypertension comes to the physician because of muscle cramps and weakness. His home medications also include amlodipine. His blood pressure today is 176/87 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The precordial leads of a 12-lead ECG are shown. The addition of which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?
(A) Torsemide (B) Nifedipine (C) Eplerenone (D) Hydralazine
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has started hydrochlorothiazide. He now presents with muscle cramps and weakness and an ECG that supports the diagnosis of hypokalemia. The addition of (A) Torsemide is a loop diuretic and would likely aggravate the hypokalemia, (B) Nifedipine is a calcium antagonist and would not alleviate the hypocalcemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potassium-sparing diuretic and would likely decrease the chance of hypokalemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potent vasodilator and would not decrease the risk of hypokalemia. The answer is (C).

Q: A 57-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe pain around her right eye, blurred vision in the same eye, and a headache for the past 4 hours. She is nauseous but has not vomited. She can see colored bright circles when she looks at a light source. She is currently being treated for a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. She appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows visual acuity of 20/20 in the left eye and counting fingers at 5 feet in the right eye. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. Intravenous analgesia and antiemetics are administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Perform ultrasound biomicroscopy (B) Perform gonioscopy (C) Perform fundoscopy (D) Administer topical steroids
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has severe pain, blurred vision, and a headache. She is also nauseous but has not vomited. She can see bright colored circles when she looks at a light source. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. The tentative (most likely) diagnosis, given the patient's symptoms, is acute primary angle-closure glaucoma. Analgesics have been administered. The next step is to confirm the tentative diagnosis using the gold standard test. (A) ultrasound biomicroscopy could be used but are not widely available, (B) Gonioscopy is the gold-standard test to confirm the diagnosis of acute primary angle-closure glaucoma, (C) fundoscopy is not as reliable as gonioscopy, (D) topical steroids is not relevant, the possible medical therapy would be timolol, apraclonidine or pilocarpine. The most appropriate next step in management is to administer intravenous analgesia and antiemetics. The answer is (B).

Q: A 55-year-old man with a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia presents for follow-up 4 days into the treatment of a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. His symptoms have resolved, and he reports no problems with urination, with the exception of a weak urine stream and hesitancy, which he has had for the past 2 years. At the time of this visit, the patient is afebrile; the blood pressure is 130/88 mm Hg and the heart rate is 80/min. There is no flank tenderness. A urinalysis reveals no leukocytes and is negative for esterase. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality:
Prior treatment
BUN 12 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL
Today’s visit
BUN 13 mg/dL
Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL
(A) Reassure the patient, stop trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and repeat the measurement in 1–2 weeks (B) Schedule an intravenous pyelography for urinary obstruction (C) Schedule a cystoscopy for urethral obstruction (D) Admit the patient for further management of acute interstitial nephritis
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia. These are both risk factors for urinary tract infections. The patient is being treated with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for a urinary tract infection. The symptoms have resolved, but the patient has a weak urine stream and hesitancy. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality: BUN 12 mg/dL, Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL (prior treatment) vs BUN 13 mg/dL, Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL (today’s visit). The BUN and creatinine levels have increased from the prior visit. This could be due to acute interstitial nephritis. A known but rare side effect of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Interstitial nephritis should be suspected if there is an elevated creatinine and a urinalysis that shows white cells, white cell casts, and, in some cases, eosinophiluria. Since none of the urinalysis results is present and the patient has no typical symptoms such as fever, rash, or acute interstitial nephritis is an unlikely diagnosis. The answer is (A).

Q: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles for the past 16 months. She began having symptoms of insomnia and depression 10 months ago. More recently, she has been having difficulties rising from a chair. She has a 2-year history of hypertension. Current medications include citalopram and hydrochlorothiazide. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb). BMI is 36 kg/m2. Her pulse is 92/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 134/76 mm Hg. She appears tired and has a full, plethoric face and central obesity. Examination of the skin shows violaceous linear striations on her lower abdomen. Two midnight serum cortisol studies show measurements of 288 μg/L and 253 μg/L (N < 90); a 24-hour urinary cortisol measurement was 395 μg (N < 300). Upon follow-up laboratory examination, the patient's serum ACTH levels were also elevated at 136 pg/mL (N = 7–50). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
(A) MRI of the head with contrast (B) Measure ACTH levels in inferior petrosal sinuses (C) High-dose dexamethasone suppression test (D) CT scan of the abdomen with contrast
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has Cushing's syndrome, which is characterized by weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles. She also has symptoms of insomnia and depression, which could be caused by Cushing's syndrome. Additionally, she has difficulties rising from a chair, which could be caused by muscle weakness. The two elevated serum cortisol measurements and the elevated ACTH levels confirm the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome. A high dose dexamethasone suppression test will help determine if the cause of Cushing's syndrome is Cushing's disease (CS caused by pituitary hypersecretion of ACTH) or ectopic ACTH syndrome (CS caused by nonpituitary ACTH-secreting tumors). Since the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome is established, the most appropriate next step is to distinguish between Cushing's disease and ectopic ACTH syndrome using the high-dose dexamethasone suppression test. The answer is (C).

Q: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a nonpruritic rash. He has been feeling more tired than usual and occasionally experiences pain in his wrists and ankles. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows multiple, erythematous, purpuric papules on his trunk and extremities that do not blanch when pressed. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The patient's hemoglobin is 14 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9,500/mm3, and platelet count is 228,000/mm3. Urinalysis and liver function tests are within normal limits. The test for rheumatoid factor is positive. Serum ANA is negative. Serum complement levels are decreased. Serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation shows increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. Testing for cryoglobulins shows no precipitate after 24 hours. Chest x-ray and ECG show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Rapid plasma reagin test (B) Hepatitis C serology (C) pANCA assay (D) Bence Jones protein test
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a rash, fatigue, and pain in his wrists and ankles. He has normal hemoglobin (normal range 13.8-17.2 g/dL), normal leukocyte count (normal range 4500-11000 wbc/microliter), and normal platelet count (normal range 150-450 platelets/microliter). His serum complement levels are decreased. His serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation show increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. The cryoglobulin precipitation test is normal, ruling out cryoglobulinemia. Serum ANA is negative, so Lupus is less likely. Physical examination and symptoms are consistent with possible non-cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. The most likely associated diagnosis is Hepatitis C. The answer is (B).

Q: A 72-year-old woman with a 40 pack-year history of smoking presents to your office with jaundice. After a thorough workup, you determine that the patient has pancreatic cancer. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial statement to inform the patient of her condition?
(A) "Have you ever heard of pancreatic cancer?" (B) "I have bad news I need to share with you. Please sit down so we can discuss." (C) "Have you designated a healthcare proxy?" (D) "Your test results are consistent with a pancreatic adenocarcinoma."
A: Let's think step by step.
question: Q: A 72-year-old woman with a 40 pack-year history of smoking presents to your office with jaundice. After a thorough workup, you determine that the patient has pancreatic cancer. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial statement to inform the patient of her condition?
options: (A) "Have you ever heard of pancreatic cancer?" (B) "I have bad news I need to share with you. Please sit down so we can discuss." (C) "Have you designated a healthcare proxy?" (D) "Your test results are consistent with a pancreatic adenocarcinoma."
outputs:
The patient has jaundice and the diagnosis of pancreatic cancer has been confirmed. The patient must be informed of her diagnosis in a sensitive and compassionate manner. The best approach would be to first acknowledge the patient's symptoms and then provide a clear and concise explanation of the diagnosis. The answer is (B).

Q: A 35-year-old man comes to the emergency department with a complaint of sudden onset of severe chest pain. He is currently smoking a pack of cigarettes a day. He has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. His blood pressure is 180/110 mm Hg, pulse is 120/min, respirations are 24/min, and temperature is 98.6°F (37°C). Physical examination shows jugular venous distension, a regular cardiac rhythm, and a grade II/VI systolic murmur at the left lower sternal border. There is no evidence of a pulmonary embolism. An ECG shows ST segment elevation in leads V2 through V6. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Administer intravenous unfractionated heparin (B) Administer sublingual nitroglycerin (C) Perform an urgent coronary angiogram (D) Administer intravenous metoprolol
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has sudden onset severe chest pain, a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia, and a positive ECG. He has a high risk of having an acute coronary syndrome. The most appropriate next step is to immediately administer sublingual nitroglycerin, as it is a vasodilator that will decrease the workload on the heart by decreasing the blood pressure and heart rate. This will help to relieve the patient's symptoms. The answer is (B).

Q: A 45-year-old woman with a history of migraine headaches presents to the emergency department with a severe headache. She has tried over-the-counter pain medications with minimal relief. She has no focal neurological deficits. Her temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a normal neurological examination. A non-contrast head CT scan is obtained and shows a 1.3 cm left frontal intracerebral hemorrhage. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Administer intravenous metoclopramide (B) Administer intravenous labetalol (C) Perform cerebral angiography (D) Administer intravenous haloperidol
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of migraine headaches and presents with a severe headache. She has tried over-the-counter pain medications with minimal relief. She has no focal neurological deficits. A non-contrast head CT scan shows a 1.3 cm left frontal intracerebral hemorrhage. The most appropriate next step is to administer intravenous metoclopramide, as it is a dopamine receptor antagonist that will help to relieve the patient's symptoms. The answer is (A).

Q: A 75-year-old woman is evaluated for a 1-week history of worsening left knee pain. She has a history of osteoarthritis and has been taking naproxen without relief. She has no history of previous knee injuries or surgery. On physical examination, the patient walks with a cane and has a noticeable limp. There is swelling and warmth of the left knee. The patient's knee is tender to palpation over the medial tibial plateau. The patient's knee flexion is limited to 90 degrees. The patient's blood pressure is 140/80 mm Hg, pulse is 80/min, respirations are 18/min, and temperature is 98.6°F (37°C). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

Q: A 40-year-old man is referred to an optometrist. He complains of mild vision impairment over the last 6 months. His vision has continued to slowly deteriorate and his condition is now affecting his night driving. Past medical history is significant for well-controlled schizophrenia. He takes a low-potency typical antipsychotics and a multivitamin every day. He has been compliant with his medication and has regular follow-up visits. What is the best first step in the management of this patient’s symptoms?
(A) Decrease medication dosage (B) Reassurance (C) Ocular examination under anesthesia (D) Slit-lamp examination
A: Let's think step by step.
question: Q: A 40-year-old man is referred to an optometrist. He complains of mild vision impairment over the last 6 months. His vision has continued to slowly deteriorate and his condition is now affecting his night driving. Past medical history is significant for well-controlled schizophrenia. He takes a low-potency typical antipsychotics and a multivitamin every day. He has been compliant with his medication and has regular follow-up visits. What is the best first step in the management of this patient’s symptoms?
options: (A) Decrease medication dosage (B) Reassurance (C) Ocular examination under anesthesia (D) Slit-lamp examination
outputs:
The patient has mild vision impairment that has been slowly deteriorating over the last 6 months, and is now affecting his night driving. He has a history of schizophrenia, which is well-controlled with medication. The patient's symptoms could be due to a variety of causes, including cataracts, glaucoma, or age-related macular degeneration. The best first step in the management of this patient's symptoms is to perform a slit-lamp examination to evaluate the anterior segment of the eye, which would help identify any abnormalities in the cornea, iris, or lens. The answer is (D).

Q: A 28-year-old woman is evaluated for a 1-day history of sudden onset of severe headache, fever, and neck stiffness. She has no significant medical history. On examination, her temperature is 102.6°F (39.2°C), blood pressure is 128/82 mm Hg, and pulse is 110/min. She appears ill and has a stiff neck. There is no evidence of meningism. A complete blood cell count shows a white blood cell count of 18,000/mm3, with 80% polymorphonuclear neutrophils. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
(A) Meningitis (B) Encephalitis (C) Subarachnoid hemorrhage (D) Acute bacterial sinusitis
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a 1-day history of sudden onset of severe headache, fever, and neck stiffness. She has no significant medical history. On examination, her temperature is elevated, blood pressure is normal, and pulse is tachycardic. She appears ill and has a stiff neck. There is no evidence of meningism. The complete blood cell count shows a white blood cell count of 18,000/mm3, with 80% polymorphonuclear neutrophils. The patient's symptoms and laboratory results are consistent with acute bacterial sinusitis. The answer is (D).

Q: A 45-year-old woman is evaluated for a 2-day history of worsening left knee pain. She has a history of osteoarthritis and has been taking naproxen as needed. She denies any recent trauma or injuries. On examination, her temperature is normal, blood pressure is 128/82 mm Hg, and pulse is 70/min. The left knee is swollen and tender to palpation. There is no evidence of effusion. A knee radiograph shows a displacement of the lateral tibial plateau. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Arthrocentesis (B) MRI of the knee (C) Immobilization with a hinged brace (D) Initiation of corticosteroid therapy
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a 2-day history of worsening left knee pain, with a history of osteoarthritis and recent use of naproxen. She denies any recent trauma or injuries. On examination, the left knee is swollen and tender to palpation, and there is no evidence of effusion. A knee radiograph shows a displacement of the lateral tibial plateau. The patient's symptoms and imaging results are consistent with a knee fracture. The most appropriate next step in management would be immobilization with a hinged brace. The answer is (C).

(C) Eplerenone is a potassium-sparing diuretic and would likely decrease the chance of hypokalemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potent vasodilator and would not decrease the risk of hypokalemia. The answer is (C).

Q: A 57-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe pain around her right eye, blurred vision in the same eye, and a headache for the past 4 hours. She is nauseous but has not vomited. She can see colored bright circles when she looks at a light source. She is currently being treated for a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. She appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows visual acuity of 20/20 in the left eye and counting fingers at 5 feet in the right eye. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. Intravenous analgesia and antiemetics are administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Perform ultrasound biomicroscopy (B) Perform gonioscopy (C) Perform fundoscopy (D) Administer topical steroids
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has severe pain, blurred vision, and a headache. She is also nauseous but has not vomited. She can see bright colored circles when she looks at a light source. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. The tentative (most likely) diagnosis, given the patient's symptoms, is acute primary angle-closure glaucoma. Analgesics have been administered. The next step is to confirm the tentative diagnosis using the gold standard test. (A) ultrasound biomicroscopy could be used but are not widely available, (B) Gonioscopy is the gold-standard test to confirm the diagnosis of acute primary angle-closure glaucoma, (C) fundoscopy is not as reliable as gonioscopy, (D) topical steroids is not relevant, the possible medical therapy would be timolol, apraclonidine or pilocarpine. The most appropriate next step in management is to administer intravenous analgesia and antiemetics. The answer is (B).

Q: A 55-year-old man with a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia presents for follow-up 4 days into the treatment of a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. His symptoms have resolved, and he reports no problems with urination, with the exception of a weak urine stream and hesitancy, which he has had for the past 2 years. At the time of this visit, the patient is afebrile; the blood pressure is 130/88 mm Hg and the heart rate is 80/min. There is no flank tenderness. A urinalysis reveals no leukocytes and is negative for esterase. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality:
Prior treatment
BUN 12 mg/dL
Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL
Today’s visit
BUN 13 mg/dL
Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL
(A) Reassure the patient, stop trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and repeat the measurement in 1–2 weeks (B) Schedule an intravenous pyelography for urinary obstruction (C) Schedule a cystoscopy for urethral obstruction (D) Admit the patient for further management of acute interstitial nephritis
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension and benign prostate hyperplasia. These are both risk factors for urinary tract infections. The patient is being treated with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for a urinary tract infection. The symptoms have resolved, but the patient has a weak urine stream and hesitancy. The urinalysis reveals 2 red blood cells (RBCs)/ high power field (HPF), and there are no casts on urinary sediment analysis. The physician, however, notices the following abnormality: BUN 12 mg/dL, Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL (prior treatment) vs BUN 13 mg/dL, Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL (today’s visit). The BUN and creatinine levels have increased from the prior visit. This could be due to acute interstitial nephritis. A known but rare side effect of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Interstitial nephritis should be suspected if there is an elevated creatinine and a urinalysis that shows white cells, white cell casts, and, in some cases, eosinophiluria. Since none of the urinalysis results is present and the patient has no typical symptoms such as fever, rash, or acute interstitial nephritis is an unlikely diagnosis. The answer is (A).

Q: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles for the past 16 months. She began having symptoms of insomnia and depression 10 months ago. More recently, she has been having difficulties rising from a chair. She has a 2-year history of hypertension. Current medications include citalopram and hydrochlorothiazide. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb). BMI is 36 kg/m2. Her pulse is 92/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 134/76 mm Hg. She appears tired and has a full, plethoric face and central obesity. Examination of the skin shows violaceous linear striations on her lower abdomen. Two midnight serum cortisol studies show measurements of 288 μg/L and 253 μg/L (N < 90); a 24-hour urinary cortisol measurement was 395 μg (N < 300). Upon follow-up laboratory examination, the patient's serum ACTH levels were also elevated at 136 pg/mL (N = 7–50). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
(A) MRI of the head with contrast (B) Measure ACTH levels in inferior petrosal sinuses (C) High-dose dexamethasone suppression test (D) CT scan of the abdomen with contrast
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has Cushing's syndrome, which is characterized by weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles. She also has symptoms of insomnia and depression, which could be caused by Cushing's syndrome. Additionally, she has difficulties rising from a chair, which could be caused by muscle weakness. The two elevated serum cortisol measurements and the elevated ACTH levels confirm the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome. A high dose dexamethasone suppression test will help determine if the cause of Cushing's syndrome is Cushing's disease (CS caused by pituitary hypersecretion of ACTH) or ectopic ACTH syndrome (CS caused by nonpituitary ACTH-secreting tumors). Since the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome is established, the most appropriate next step is to distinguish between Cushing's disease and ectopic ACTH syndrome using the high-dose dexamethasone suppression test. The answer is (C).

Q: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a nonpruritic rash. He has been feeling more tired than usual and occasionally experiences pain in his wrists and ankles. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows multiple, erythematous, purpuric papules on his trunk and extremities that do not blanch when pressed. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The patient's hemoglobin is 14 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9,500/mm3, and platelet count is 228,000/mm3. Urinalysis and liver function tests are within normal limits. The test for rheumatoid factor is positive. Serum ANA is negative. Serum complement levels are decreased. Serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation shows increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. Testing for cryoglobulins shows no precipitate after 24 hours. Chest x-ray and ECG show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Rapid plasma reagin test (B) Hepatitis C serology (C) pANCA assay (D) Bence Jones protein test
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a rash, fatigue, and pain in his wrists and ankles. He has normal hemoglobin (normal range 13.8-17.2 g/dL), normal leukocyte count (normal range 4500-11000 wbc/microliter), and normal platelet count (normal range 150-450 platelets/microliter). His serum complement levels are decreased. His serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation show increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. The cryoglobulin precipitation test is normal, ruling out cryoglobulinemia. Serum ANA is negative, so Lupus is less likely. Physical examination and symptoms are consistent with possible non-cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. The most likely associated diagnosis is Hepatitis C. The answer is (B).

Q: A 65-year-old man presents with a 6-month history of repeated falls, postural dizziness, progressive fatigue, generalized weakness and a 13.6 kg (30 lb) weight loss. He is a vegetarian. The patient’s family says that he had been high functioning but has had significant behavioral changes over the past year. The patient denies any smoking history, alcohol consumption, or illicit drug use. No significant family history. His vital signs include: blood pressure 90/50 mm Hg without postural changes, pulse 92/min, respiratory rate 16/min, temperature 37.0℃ (98.6℉). Physical examination reveals a poorly groomed, disheveled, thin man. He is irritable, paranoid, and delusional but denies any hallucinations. An unstable, wide-based ataxic gait is noted. Laboratory results are significant for the following:
Hb 6.1 g/dL
MCV 109 fL
Platelets 90,0000/mm3
Total count 3,000/mm3
Reticulocyte count 0.8%
A peripheral blood smear demonstrates hypersegmented neutrophils. Anti-intrinsic factor antibodies are negative. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
 
(A) Hypothyroidism (B) Folate deficiency (C) Vitamin B12 deficiency (D) Parvovirus infection
A: Let's think step by step.

Q: A 42-year-old man presents to establish care with a family physician after having progressively worsening back pain. He has recently migrated from Sweden and has not had any checkups in the last 3 years. He first started having back pain 3 years ago, but his pain has begun to be excruciating in the mornings. He is no longer able to get relief with over the counter medications. He also feels stiff every morning and this usually lasts between 30 minutes and an hour. Both of his knees are also very painful, particularly upon standing up from a seated position. His pain improves when he moves around, so he tries to be somewhat physically active. He also reports that he cannot use his hands for long periods of time due to joint pain and stiffness. His father and sister also have joint issues, and his mother was recently diagnosed with osteoporosis. He has been a smoker for 13 years. Upon physical examination, his wrist and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints are warm and swollen. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
(A) Testing for serum Ca and PTH (B) Calcium and Vitamin D prescription (C) Testing for serum ESR and autoantibodies (D) Testing for serum ferritin
A: Let's think step by step.
question: Q: A 42-year-old man presents to establish care with a family physician after having progressively worsening back pain. He has recently migrated from Sweden and has not had any checkups in the last 3 years. He first started having back pain 3 years ago, but his pain has begun to be excruciating in the mornings. He is no longer able to get relief with over the counter medications. He also feels stiff every morning and this usually lasts between 30 minutes and an hour. Both of his knees are also very painful, particularly upon standing up from a seated position. His pain improves when he moves around, so he tries to be somewhat physically active. He also reports that he cannot use his hands for long periods of time due to joint pain and stiffness. His father and sister also have joint issues, and his mother was recently diagnosed with osteoporosis. He has been a smoker for 13 years. Upon physical examination, his wrist and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints are warm and swollen. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
options: (A) Testing for serum Ca and PTH (B) Calcium and Vitamin D prescription (C) Testing for serum ESR and autoantibodies (D) Testing for serum ferritin
outputs:
The patient has a 3-year history of back pain that has worsened recently. He also has knee pain, hand pain, and morning stiffness that lasts for 30 minutes to an hour. His family history suggests a possible genetic predisposition to joint issues. The patient is a smoker, which could contribute to his symptoms. The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings are consistent with a possible inflammatory arthritis, such as rheumatoid arthritis. The next best step in management would be to test for serum ESR and autoantibodies to support the diagnosis of inflammatory arthritis. The answer is (C).

Q: A 45-year-old woman is evaluated in the emergency department because of sudden onset of severe headache, blurred vision, and vomiting. She is currently being treated for hypertension with lisinopril. She has no history of migraines. Her temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 190/110 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities except for conjunctival injection. The patient appears uncomfortable. Fundoscopic examination shows grade 3 hypertensive retinopathy. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Administer intravenous metoclopramide (B) Administer intravenous furosemide (C) Administer intravenous labetalol (D) Administer intravenous hydralazine
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a sudden onset of severe headache, blurred vision, and vomiting. She has a history of hypertension and is currently being treated with lisinopril. Her blood pressure is elevated at 190/110 mm Hg. The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings are consistent with a hypertensive emergency. The patient's fundoscopic examination shows grade 3 hypertensive retinopathy, indicating damage to the blood vessels in the retina. The most appropriate next step in management would be to administer intravenous labetalol to lower the patient's blood pressure and prevent further damage. The answer is (C).

Q: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles for the past 16 months. She began having symptoms of insomnia and depression 10 months ago. More recently, she has been having difficulties rising from a chair. She has a 2-year history of hypertension. Current medications include citalopram and hydrochlorothiazide. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb). BMI is 36 kg/m2. Her pulse is 92/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 134/76 mm Hg. She appears tired and has a full, plethoric face and central obesity. Examination of the skin shows violaceous linear striations on her lower abdomen. Two midnight serum cortisol studies show measurements of 288 μg/L and 253 μg/L (N < 90); a 24-hour urinary cortisol measurement was 395 μg (N < 300). Upon follow-up laboratory examination, the patient's serum ACTH levels were also elevated at 136 pg/mL (N = 7–50). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
(A) MRI of the head with contrast (B) Measure ACTH levels in inferior petrosal sinuses (C) High-dose dexamethasone suppression test (D) CT scan of the abdomen with contrast
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has Cushing's syndrome, which is characterized by weight gain, generalized weakness, and irregular menstrual cycles. She also has symptoms of insomnia and depression, which could be caused by Cushing's syndrome. Additionally, she has difficulties rising from a chair, which could be caused by muscle weakness. The two elevated serum cortisol measurements and the elevated ACTH levels confirm the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome. A high dose dexamethasone suppression test will help determine if the cause of Cushing's syndrome is Cushing's disease (CS caused by pituitary hypersecretion of ACTH) or ectopic ACTH syndrome (CS caused by nonpituitary ACTH-secreting tumors). Since the diagnosis of Cushing's syndrome is established, the most appropriate next step is to distinguish between Cushing's disease and ectopic ACTH syndrome using the high-dose dexamethasone suppression test. The answer is (C).

Q: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a nonpruritic rash. He has been feeling more tired than usual and occasionally experiences pain in his wrists and ankles. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows multiple, erythematous, purpuric papules on his trunk and extremities that do not blanch when pressed. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The patient's hemoglobin is 14 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9,500/mm3, and platelet count is 228,000/mm3. Urinalysis and liver function tests are within normal limits. The test for rheumatoid factor is positive. Serum ANA is negative. Serum complement levels are decreased. Serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation shows increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. Testing for cryoglobulins shows no precipitate after 24 hours. Chest x-ray and ECG show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Rapid plasma reagin test (B) Hepatitis C serology (C) pANCA assay (D) Bence Jones protein test
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a rash, fatigue, and pain in his wrists and ankles. He has normal hemoglobin (normal range 13.8-17.2 g/dL), normal leukocyte count (normal range 4500-11000 wbc/microliter), and normal platelet count (normal range 150-450 platelets/microliter). His serum complement levels are decreased. His serum protein electrophoresis and immunofixation show increased gammaglobulins with pronounced polyclonal IgM and IgG bands. The cryoglobulin precipitation test is normal, ruling out cryoglobulinemia. Serum ANA is negative, so Lupus is less likely. Physical examination and symptoms are consistent with possible non-cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. The most likely associated diagnosis is Hepatitis C. The answer is (B).

Q: A previously healthy 28-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of dizziness and palpitations for 2 days. Prior to the onset of the symptoms, he attended a bachelor party where he lost several drinking games. An ECG is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
(A) Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation (B) Brugada syndrome (C) Ventricular tachycardia (D) Sick sinus syndrome
A: Let's think step by step.
question: Q: A previously healthy 28-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of dizziness and palpitations for 2 days. Prior to the onset of the symptoms, he attended a bachelor party where he lost several drinking games. An ECG is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
options: (A) Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation (B) Brugada syndrome (C) Ventricular tachycardia (D) Sick sinus syndrome
outputs:
The patient has been experiencing dizziness and palpitations for 2 days. He has a history of binge drinking at a bachelor party. He has no history of previous cardiac problems. The patient's ECG shows a prolonged QTc interval and a coved-shaped ST segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVf. This is consistent with alcohol-induced prolonged QTc syndrome, a potentially life-threatening condition that can cause torsades de pointes, a polymorphic ventricular tachycardia. The answer is (A).

Q: A 57-year-old woman is evaluated for a 6-month history of fatigue and a 2-month history of increasing left knee pain. She has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. She takes no medications. Physical examination shows a swollen left knee with warmth, erythema, and moderate tenderness to palpation. There is no joint effusion or warmth to the touch. The patient walks with a cane. Blood tests show a hemoglobin of 12 g/dL, leukocyte count of 7,000/mm3, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 70 mm/h. Urinalysis shows proteinuria of 1,000 mg/day and active sediment. Imaging studies are ordered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) MRI of the knee (B) Ultrasound of the kidneys (C) Arthrocentesis (D) Intravenous methylprednisolone
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. She presents with a swollen left knee, warmth, erythema, and moderate tenderness to palpation. There is no joint effusion or warmth to the touch. The patient walks with a cane. The urinalysis shows proteinuria of 1,000 mg/day and active sediment. The patient has signs and symptoms of nephrotic syndrome and possible inflammatory arthritis. The patient's urinalysis shows proteinuria and active sediment, consistent with membranous nephropathy. The most appropriate next step is to confirm the diagnosis of membranous nephropathy using a kidney biopsy. The answer is (B).

Q: A 65-year-old man is evaluated for a 6-month history of worsening dyspnea, chronic cough, and chest tightness. He has a 40-pack-year smoking history and stopped smoking 10 years ago. He has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Physical examination shows a blood pressure of 160/90 mm Hg, respiratory rate of 28/min, and oxygen saturation of 88% on room air. There is a cardiac murmur, and lung examination shows bilateral crackles and wheezes. Chest x-ray shows a prominent right hilar shadow and a flattened diaphragm. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Echocardiogram (B) CT angiogram (C) Pulmonary function tests (D) Bronchoscopy
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has a history of smoking and stopped 10 years ago. He has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He presents with worsening dyspnea, chronic cough, and chest tightness. Physical examination shows a cardiac murmur, and lung examination shows bilateral crackles and wheezes. Chest x-ray shows a prominent right hilar shadow and a flattened diaphragm. The patient's symptoms and physical examination are consistent with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). The most appropriate next step is to confirm the diagnosis using pulmonary function tests. The answer is (C).

Q: A 46-year-old woman is evaluated for a 1-month history of worsening left knee pain. She has a history of hyperlipidemia and takes atorvastatin. She has no history of previous knee injuries. Physical examination shows a swollen left knee with moderate tenderness to palpation

Q: Four weeks after starting hydrochlorothiazide, a 49-year-old man with hypertension comes to the physician because of muscle cramps and weakness. His home medications also include amlodipine. His blood pressure today is 176/87 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The precordial leads of a 12-lead ECG are shown. The addition of which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?
(A) Torsemide (B) Nifedipine (C) Eplerenone (D) Hydralazine
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has started hydrochlorothiazide. He now presents with muscle cramps and weakness and an ECG that supports the diagnosis of hypokalemia. The addition of (A) Torsemide is a loop diuretic and would likely aggravate the hypokalemia, (B) Nifedipine is a calcium antagonist and would not alleviate the hypocalcemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potassium-sparing diuretic and would likely decrease the chance of hypokalemia. (C) Eplerenone is a potent vasodilator and would not decrease the risk of hypokalemia. The answer is (C).

Q: A 57-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe pain around her right eye, blurred vision in the same eye, and a headache for the past 4 hours. She is nauseous but has not vomited. She can see colored bright circles when she looks at a light source. She is currently being treated for a urinary tract infection with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. She appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows visual acuity of 20/20 in the left eye and counting fingers at 5 feet in the right eye. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. Intravenous analgesia and antiemetics are administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Perform ultrasound biomicroscopy (B) Perform gonioscopy (C) Perform fundoscopy (D) Administer topical steroids
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has severe pain, blurred vision, and a headache. She is also nauseous but has not vomited. She can see bright colored circles when she looks at a light source. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and edema of the cornea. The right pupil is dilated and fixed. The tentative (most likely) diagnosis, given the patient's symptoms, is acute primary angle-closure glaucoma. Analgesics have been administered. The next step is to confirm the tentative diagnosis using the gold standard test. (A) ultrasound biomicroscopy could be used but are not widely available, (B) Gonioscopy is the gold-standard test to confirm the diagnosis of acute primary angle-closure glaucoma, (C) fundoscopy is not as reliable as gonioscopy, (D) topical steroids is not relevant, the possible medical therapy would be timolol, apraclonidine or pilocarpine. The most appropriate next step in management is to administer intravenous analgesia and antiemetics. The answer is (B).

Q: A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician because of fatigue, abdominal cramps, watery diarrhea, and a weight loss of 4 kg (8.8 lb) over the last 4 months. She has recently avoided drinking alcohol and eating spicy food because it worsens her diarrhea and causes episodes of heart palpitations and reddening of the face and neck. She takes lisinopril for hypertension. Her temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 149/90 mm Hg. The abdomen is soft, and there is mild tenderness to palpation with no guarding or rebound. Laboratory studies show an increased urine 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid concentration. Further evaluation of this patient will most likely show which of the following?
(A) Achlorhydria (B) Adrenal medullary mass (C) Multiple peptic ulcers (D) Pulmonic valve stenosis
A: Let's think step by step.
question: Q: A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician because of fatigue, abdominal cramps, watery diarrhea, and a weight loss of 4 kg (8.8 lb) over the last 4 months. She has recently avoided drinking alcohol and eating spicy food because it worsens her diarrhea and causes episodes of heart palpitations and reddening of the face and neck. She takes lisinopril for hypertension. Her temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 149/90 mm Hg. The abdomen is soft, and there is mild tenderness to palpation with no guarding or rebound. Laboratory studies show an increased urine 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid concentration. Further evaluation of this patient will most likely show which of the following?
options: (A) Achlorhydria (B) Adrenal medullary mass (C) Multiple peptic ulcers (D) Pulmonic valve stenosis
outputs: The patient has fatigue, abdominal cramps, watery diarrhea, and weight loss. She has recently avoided drinking alcohol and eating spicy food because it worsens her diarrhea and causes episodes of heart palpitations and reddening of the face and neck. The patient's urine 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid concentration is increased. The patient's symptoms and laboratory results are consistent with carcinoid syndrome. Carcinoid syndrome is caused by the release of excessive amounts of serotonin and other vasoactive substances from a carcinoid tumor. Carcinoid tumors are rare, but they are the most common type of neuroendocrine tumors. The tumors are usually found in the small intestine, but they can also be found in other parts of the digestive system. The patient's history of hypertension and the current use of lisinopril suggest that the tumor is likely to be in the small intestine. The next step in management would be to perform an Octreoscan to confirm the diagnosis. The answer is (B).

Q: A 66-year-old man presents to the emergency department due to a productive cough. His cough has been increasing in frequency and severity over the course of 3 days, and his sputum production has increased in volume. The color of his sputum is yellow-green. He denies any chest pain or palpitations but has experienced worsening shortness of breath with exertion and at rest, which is above his baseline. He has not noticed any changes in his weight or edema in his lower extremities. He denies any recent history of long travel. Medical history is significant for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). He has been hospitalized four times for similar symptoms within the last year. He has smoked approximately 1 pack of cigarettes per day for the past 45 years. His temperature is 102°F (38.9°C), blood pressure is 156/94 mmHg, pulse is 101/min, and respirations are 26/min with an oxygen saturation of 85% on room air. On physical exam, the patient has difficulty speaking, and there is asynchronous motion between the chest and abdomen with respiration. Wheezing is appreciated on pulmonary auscultation. An ECG demonstrates normal sinus rhythm. A chest radiograph is obtained, and he is administered supplemental oxygen. He is started on ipratropium, albuterol, and methylprednisolone. Which of the following should be added to this patient's treatment regimen?
(A) Cefazolin (B) Ceftriaxone (C) Levofloxacin (D) Penicillin
A: Let's think step by step.
question: Q: A 66-year-old man presents to the emergency department due to a productive cough. His cough has been increasing in frequency and severity over the course of 3 days, and his sputum production has increased in volume. The color of his sputum is yellow-green. He denies any chest pain or palpitations but has experienced worsening shortness of breath with exertion and at rest, which is above his baseline. He has not noticed any changes in his weight or edema in his lower extremities. He denies any recent history of long travel. Medical history is significant for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). He has been hospitalized four times for similar symptoms within the last year. He has smoked approximately 1 pack of cigarettes per day for the past 45 years. His temperature is 102°F (38.9°C), blood pressure is 156/94 mmHg, pulse is 101/min, and respirations are 26/min with an oxygen saturation of 85% on room air. On physical exam, the patient has difficulty speaking, and there is asynchronous motion between the chest and abdomen with respiration. Wheezing is appreciated on pulmonary auscultation. An ECG demonstrates normal sinus rhythm. A chest radiograph is obtained, and he is administered supplemental oxygen. He is started on ipratropium, albuterol, and methylprednisolone. Which of the following should be added to this patient's treatment regimen?
options: (A) Cefazolin (B) Ceftriaxone (C) Levofloxacin (D) Penicillin
outputs:
The patient has a productive cough, worsening shortness of breath, and difficulty speaking. He has a history of COPD, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. He has been hospitalized four times for similar symptoms within the last year. His physical examination shows wheezing on pulmonary auscultation. His chest radiograph is not provided. Given the patient's history of COPD and the symptoms described, it is likely that the patient is experiencing an exacerbation of COPD. The addition of antibiotics to the patient's treatment regimen is appropriate, as bacterial infections can exacerbate COPD symptoms. The choice of antibiotic depends on the severity of the exacerbation and the patient's history of antibiotic use. In this case, the patient's history of smoking and hospitalizations for similar symptoms suggests a severe exacerbation, and broad-spectrum antibiotics are warranted. The choice between ceftriaxone and levofloxacin is appropriate, as both are effective against common respiratory pathogens. However, given the patient's history of smoking, the risk of Pseudomonas aeruginosa infection is higher, and piperacillin-tazobactam (Zosyn) or ceftriaxone (Rocephin) would be a better choice. The answer is (B).

Q: A 35-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of fatigue, weakness, and weight loss. She has been having difficulty walking because of weakness in her legs. She has no fever, chest pain, or shortness of breath. She has no history of cancer. She has been taking oral contraceptives for 10 years. She has no history of smoking or drug use. Her blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg, pulse is 78/min, and respirations are 18/min. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Urinalysis shows proteinuria (300 mg/day), and a 24-hour urine protein collection shows 1,500 mg/day. The patient's hemoglobin is 10 g/dL, leukocyte count is 4,000/mm3, and platelet count is 150,000/mm3. Serum creatinine is 1.1 mg/dL, and a 24-hour urine protein collection shows 1,500 mg/day. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
(A) Perform kidney biopsy (B) Start corticosteroids (C) Start hydroxychloroquine (D) Start blood transfusions
A: Let's think step by step. The patient has fatigue, weakness, and weight loss for 1 year, difficulty walking because of weakness in her legs, and proteinuria (300 mg/day) on urinalysis. The 24-hour urine protein collection shows 1,500 mg/day. The patient has no history of cancer, smoking, or drug use. The patient's hemoglobin is 10 g/dL, leukocyte count is 4,000/mm3, and platelet count is 150,000/mm3. Serum creatinine is 1.1 mg/dL. The patient is most likely experiencing membranous nephropathy, a kidney disease characterized by thickening of the glomerular basement membrane, leading to proteinuria. The most appropriate next step in management would be to perform a kidney biopsy to confirm the diagnosis. The answer is (A).

Q: A 44-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of sudden hearing loss and severe vertigo. He has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and smoking. He has been compliant with his medications and has no history of recent travel or illness. He has been experiencing worsening hearing loss over the past week and has been using cotton swabs to clean his ears. On physical examination, his blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg, pulse is 80/min, and respirations are 18/min. Otoscopic examination shows a Weber Class III/
